NEWSRACKS
§ 114.001 TITLE.
   This subchapter shall be known as and may be cited as the “Blue Island
Newsrack Ordinance”.
(Prior Code, § 114.001) (Ord. 07-068, passed 4-10-2007)
§ 114.002 PURPOSE AND INTENT.
   It is the purpose and intent of this subchapter to regulate the placement of
newsracks located on city property within the corporate limits of the city.
(Prior Code, § 114.002) (Ord. 07-068, passed 4-10-2007)
§ 114.003 DEFINITIONS.
   For the purpose of this subchapter, the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
   NEWSRACK. Any vending machine the purpose of which is to dispense,
distribute or sell newspapers, magazines, books, pamphlets, periodicals or
other literature.
   PARKWAY. The area of the street between the nearest edge of the pavement and
sidewalk; or, in areas where there is no sidewalk, that area of the street
between the nearest edge of the pavement and the property line.
   PAVEMENT. The area of the street the primary purpose being for the passage,
parking or standing of motor vehicles. PAVEMENT includes curbs, gutters and any
sewer structures.
   SIDEWALK. Any paved surface the primary purpose being for the passage of
pedestrians.
   STREET. Any area dedicated to public use for street, highway, alley or
roadway purposes, including, but not limited to, the areas of pavement, parkway
and sidewalk.
(Prior Code, § 114.003) (Ord. 07-068, passed 4-10-2007)
§ 114.004 PERMIT REQUIRED.
   (A)   It shall be unlawful for any person to place, own, maintain or operate
a newsrack located on city property within the corporate limits of the city;
except that, a newsrack may be placed, owned, maintained or operated after a
permit has been granted. A newsrack may be placed, owned, maintained or
operated only in C-1 and C-2 Zoning Districts. Application for a permit shall
be made on forms supplied by the Building Department.
   (B)   No newsrack may be located or placed:
      (1)   Within 15 feet of any fire hydrant or fire hose connection;
      (2)   Within 15 feet of any intersecting pavement or driveway;
      (3)   Within five feet of any marked crosswalk;
      (4)   In a flower bed;
      (5)   On the pavement;
      (6)   Where it reduces the width of the sidewalk or other paved portions
of the parkway available for passage to less than five feet;
      (7)   Within ten feet of any door of a building;
      (8)   On the sidewalk or parkway on the same side of the street and
immediately adjacent to a no parking zone or a no standing zone;
      (9)   On or in any handicapped access ramp;
      (10)   Fronting the curb line of Western Avenue;
      (11)   In a group containing more than four newsracks; and/or
      (12)   Within 200 of any other newsrack or group of newsracks on the same
side of the street in the same block.
   (C)   No newsrack shall exceed 50 inches in height as measured from the
ground to the highest portion of the newsrack. No newsrack shall exceed 24
inches in width as measured across the front portion of the newsrack. No
newsrack shall exceed 20 inches in depth as measured from the front of the
newsrack to the rear of the newsrack. The front and rear panels shall be of the
same width and height. The side panels shall be of the same width and height.
   (D)   All applications shall be granted or denied within 30 days after
receipt thereof. Upon the initial granting of a permit, the application shall
pay $20 permit per location. The permit shall be automatically renewable upon
the payment of a $10 annual permit fee; provided that, the location of the
newsrack complies with this section. If an application for a permit required by
this subchapter is denied, the applicant shall be notified and may request a
review by submitting a written request within seven days from the notice of
denial to the Judiciary Committee.
(Prior Code, § 114.004) (Ord. 07-068, passed 4-10-2007) Penalty, see §
10.99
§ 114.005 SECURING NEWSRACKS TO STRUCTURES.
   No person or entity shall chain or otherwise secure any newsrack to any
tree, light pole, sidewalk, parkway, traffic-control device or street sign.
(Prior Code, § 114.005) (Ord. 07-068, passed 4-10-2007) Penalty, see §
10.99
§ 114.006 AGREEMENT REQUIRED.
   (A)   In every application for a newsrack, the applicant shall provide a
color photograph of the newsrack and list the dimensions of the newsrack.
   (B)   The applicant shall also agree to the following conditions:
      (1)   Any and all costs related to the installation and maintenance or
removal of the newsrack shall be incurred by the applicant;
      (2)   The privileges granted to the applicant are non-transferable;
      (3)   Upon the removal of a newsrack, the permittee shall restore the
property where the newsrack was located to the condition of the property prior
to the installation of the newsrack, normal wear and tear excepted;
      (4)   Each newsrack shall be fully enclosed and shall secure the
materials contained therein so as to prevent the materials from potentially
littering public property;
      (5)   Each newsrack shall be maintained in a neat and clean condition and
in good repair at all times;
      (6)   Each newsrack shall have affixed to it, in a readily visible place
so as to be seen by anyone using the newsrack, a notice setting forth the name
and address of the permittee and a telephone number of a working telephone
service to call to report a malfunction; and
      (7)   Each newsrack shall not be used for advertising signs or publicity
other than advertising for the newspaper or news periodical dispensed
therefrom.
(Prior Code, § 114.006) (Ord. 07-068, passed 4-10-2007) Penalty, see §
10.99
§ 114.007 REMOVAL FOR VIOLATIONS.
   (A)   Any newsrack located in violation of any provision of this subchapter
is subject to removal by the city only after the owner thereof has been given
the opportunity for a pre-removal hearing. Prior to removal, the Building
Department shall give notice by mail addressed to the owner, which notice shall
state why the newsrack is in violation and give the owner seven days to remedy
the violation. The owner, within this period, may request a hearing before the
Judiciary Committee and present evidence to the effect that no violation
exists. If the Judiciary Committee determines that a violation does exist, then
the owner shall have seven days to remedy the violation after which the
newsrack is subject to removal by the city. If the owner fails to request a
hearing, then the city may remove the newsrack.
   (B)   The city may cause the immediate removal of any newsrack not located
in a permitted position which creates an imminent danger of personal injury or
property damage to the public.
(Prior Code, § 114.007) (Ord. 07-068, passed 4-10-2007)
§ 114.008 EFFECTIVE DATE.
   This subchapter shall be in full force and effect from and after its passage
and approval as provided by law.
(Prior Code, § 114.008) (Ord. 07-068, passed 4-10-2007)
POSTING OF BILLS AND ADVERTISEMENTS
§ 114.020 PROHIBITED POSTING.
   No person shall post, stick, stamp, tack, paint or otherwise fix or cause
the same to be done by any person, any notice, placard, bill, card, poster,
advertisement or other device calculated to attract the notice of the public to
or upon any sidewalk, crosswalk, curb or curbstone, flagstone or any other
portion or part of any sidewalk or street, lamp post, electric light,
telegraph, telephone, hydrant, shade tree or upon any bridge, pier, fence,
gate, gate post or upon any pole, box or fixture of the fire alarm, except such
as may be required by the laws of the state or the ordinances of the city.
(Prior Code, § 114.020) Penalty, see §
10.99
OUTDOOR ADVERTISING
§ 114.035 PERMIT REQUIRED.
   No billboard, signboard or sign, or other similar structure such as
described in this chapter, shall be erected or painted within the city unless a
permit therefor shall first have been secured by the person desiring to erect
or maintain such billboard, signboard or sign from the City Clerk, to whom
application for such permit shall be made; and the application shall be
accompanied by plans and specifications of the proposed billboard, signboard or
signs, and the location of the same. If the plans and specifications
accompanying the application shall be in accordance with the provisions of this
subchapter, the Building Inspector shall thereupon approve the same and the
City Clerk shall issue a permit for the erection of such billboard, signboard
or sign upon the payment by the applicant of a fee.
(Prior Code, § 114.035) Penalty, see §
10.99
§ 114.036 DEFINITION.
   For the purpose of this subchapter, the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
   BILLBOARD or SIGNBOARD or SIGN. All outdoor structures of whatever material
constructed which are erected, maintained and used for the public display of
posters, painted signs, pictures or pictorial or reading matter; except that,
such terms shall not include signs erected or maintained on roofs or signs
attached to or painted upon the walls of buildings. The term SIGN shall include
all advertising structures, having a face similar to a billboard or signboard,
but which are erected and maintained on the roofs, or attached to the walls of
buildings. The terms BILLBOARD, SIGNBOARD or SIGN shall not be held to include
any board, sign or surface used to display official notices, issued by any
court of public office or officer, or to include any board or sign having an
area of less than 25 square feet.
(Prior Code, § 114.036)
§ 114.037 SIZE LIMITATIONS.
   (A)   No billboard or signboard hereafter erected on the surface of the
ground shall exceed 12 feet in height, clear posting or painting surface.
   (B)   Every such billboard or signboard shall have an open space of not less
than two feet between the lower edge of such board and the ground.
   (C)   The face of every billboard or signboard within the city limits shall
be constructed of galvanized iron or other equally incombustible material, but
the supporting structure and framework thereof may be of wood.
   (D)   All such billboards or signboards shall be securely anchored or
fastened so as to be safe and substantial.
(Prior Code, § 114.037) Penalty, see §
10.99
§ 114.038 LOCATION RESTRICTIONS.
   No billboard or signboard shall be erected nearer to the front line of the
lot on which it is located than the main front wall of the building immediately
adjoining such billboard or signboard and in no case shall a billboard or
signboard be erected nearer to the front line of the lot than the established
building line.
(Prior Code, § 114.038) Penalty, see §
10.99
§ 114.039 PERMIT REQUIRED FOR ALTERATIONS.
   No billboard or signboard having a surface area of more than 25 square feet
shall be reconstructed or materially altered without a permit from the Building
Inspector; provided, however, that, this provision shall not apply to the
changing of any advertising matter of any billboard or signboard or the
refacing or changing of the painted panel on such billboard or signboard.
(Prior Code, § 114.039) Penalty, see §
10.99
§ 114.040 MATERIAL STANDARDS; FACE OR SIDE OF BUILDING.
   No sign, having a surface area of more than 25 square feet, shall be
hereafter attached to the face or side of any building unless the face of such
sign is wholly constructed of metal or other non-combustible material.
(Prior Code, § 114.040) Penalty, see §
10.99
§ 114.041 MATERIAL STANDARDS; ROOF OF BUILDING.
   Every sign erected on the roof of any building shall be built entirely of
metal and shall be securely fastened to the roof or walls of the building.
(Prior Code, § 114.041) Penalty, see §
10.99
§ 114.042 STRENGTH OF SIGNBOARDS.
   All billboards, signboards and signs now in existence or hereafter to be
constructed, erected or maintained shall be made, constructed, erected and
maintained of sufficient strength to withstand a wind pressure of 25 pounds per
square foot of surface.
(Prior Code, § 114.042) Penalty, see §
10.99
§ 114.043 INSPECTION; DUTIES OF BUILDING INSPECTOR.
   (A)   It shall be the duty of the Building Inspector to inspect all plans
and specifications submitted in connection with the erection, reconstruction or
alteration of any billboard, signboard or sign and to approve the same if the
method of construction and provisions made for fastening, securing, anchoring
and maintaining such billboard, signboard or sign are such as will serve to
protect the public and to render such billboard, signboard or sign safe and
substantial. It is further made the duty of the Building Inspector to exercise
supervision over all billboards, signboards and signs erected or being
maintained under the provisions of this subchapter and to cause inspection by
inspectors in the Building Inspector’s Department of all such billboards,
signboards and signs to be made once each year and more often where the
condition of the same so requires; and whenever it shall appear to the Building
Inspector that any such billboard, signboard or sign has been erected in
violation of this chapter or is in an unsafe condition or has become unstable
or insecure or is in such a condition as to be a menace to the safety or health
of the public, the Building Inspector shall thereupon issue or cause to be
issued a notice in writing to the owner of the billboard, signboard or sign or
to the person in charge, possession or control thereof, if the whereabouts of
such person is known, informing such owner or person in charge thereof, of the
violation of this subchapter and the dangerous condition of the billboard,
signboard or sign and directing such person to make alterations or repairs
thereto or to do such acts or things as are necessary or advisable to place the
billboard, signboard or sign in safe, substantial and secure condition and to
make the same comply with the requirements of this subchapter, within such
reasonable time as may be stated in the notice.
   (B)   If the owner or person in charge, possession or control of any
billboard, signboard or sign, when so notified, shall refuse, fail or neglect
to comply with and conform to the requirements of such notice, the Building
Inspector shall, upon the expiration of the time therein mentioned, alter,
change, tear down or cause to be torn down such part of the billboard,
signboard or sign as is constructed or maintained in violation of this
subchapter, and shall charge the expense to the owner or person in possession,
charge or control of the billboard, signboard or sign, which may be recovered
from the owner or person in charge by appropriate legal proceedings.
   (C)   If the owner of the billboard, signboard or sign, or the person in
charge, possession or control thereof cannot be found, or his, her or their
whereabouts cannot be ascertained, the Building Inspector shall attach or cause
to be attached to the billboard, signboard or sign, a notice of the same report
as that required to be sent to the owner or person in charge, possession or
control thereof, where the owner or person in charge is known; and if such
billboard, signboard or sign shall not have been made to conform to this
subchapter and be placed in a secure, safe and substantial condition, in
accordance with the requirements of such notice, within 30 days after such
notice shall have been attached to such billboard, signboard or sign, it shall
be the duty of the Building Inspector to thereupon cause such billboard,
signboard or sign, such portion thereof as is constructed or maintained in
violation of this subchapter, to be torn down; provided that, nothing herein
contained shall prevent the Building Inspector from adopting such precautionary
measures as may be necessary or advisable in cases of imminent danger in order
to place the billboard, signboard or sign in a safe condition, the expense of
which shall be charged to and recovered from the owner of such billboard,
signboard or sign or person in charge, possession or control thereof, in any
appropriate proceedings therefor.
   (D)   It shall be the duty of the Building Inspector to require that the
name of the person or corporation owning or in possession, charge or control of
any billboard, signboard or sign is placed upon such billboard, signboard or
sign forthwith upon the erection thereof and is kept thereon during the entire
time that such billboard, signboard or sign is maintained; and, in case the
owner of the billboard, signboard or sign, or the person in charge, possession
or control thereof, shall fail or refuse to place and maintain such name on the
same, such person shall be subject to the penalty hereinafter provided for in §
10.99 of this code of ordinances.
(Prior Code, § 114.043) Penalty, see §
10.99
§ 114.044 REPORT TO BE FILED.
   Every person engaged in the business of erecting or maintaining billboards,
signboards or signs for the purpose of display advertising shall file with the
City Clerk a full and complete report of the location and size of all existing
billboards, signboards or signs so maintained by such person, firm or
corporation.
(Prior Code, § 114.044) Penalty, see §
10.99
§ 114.045 PERMIT FEE.
   (A)   The fees to be charged for permits for the erection of billboards,
signboards or signs shall be as follows:
      (1)   First 25 lineal feet or fraction thereof: $10;
      (2)   All signs over 25 feet in length and under 50 feet in length: $15;
      (3)   All signs over 50 feet in length and under 75 feet in length: $20;
and
      (4)   All signs 75 feet in length and under 100 feet in length: $25.
   (B)   These fees shall be paid to the City Clerk at the time application is
made for the permit, and there shall also be charged an annual inspection fee
of $1 for each 25 lineal feet or fraction thereof, for each and every
billboard, signboard or sign erected.
   (C)   The fee to be paid by the person, firm or corporation who shall own,
be in possession of, or control any such billboard, signboard or sign.
(Prior Code, § 114.045)
§ 114.046 SIGNBOARDS TO BE MAINTAINED IN SANITARY CONDITION.
   Any person who shall maintain billboards, signboards or signs under the
provisions of this subchapter shall keep the same in a sanitary condition and
shall not allow waste paper or refuse from billboards, signboards or signs to
accumulate in or about the premises on which the same are erected or
maintained.
(Prior Code, § 114.046) Penalty, see §
10.99
§ 114.047 BOND REQUIRED.
   Every person engaged in the business of constructing, erecting and
maintaining billboards, signboards or signs in the city shall file with the
City Clerk a bond with sureties to be approved by the City Council, in the sum
of $10,000, conditioned that such person shall faithfully comply with the
provisions of this subchapter with reference to the construction, alteration,
maintenance and safety of such billboards, signboards and signs and for the
payment of such fees as are herein provided to be paid and, further, to save
and keep harmless the city and its officials from all damages, liability,
losses or judgments which may be claimed or recovered by any person against the
city by reason of the erection, maintenance, removal or repair of any such
billboard, signboard or sign.
(Prior Code, § 114.047)
§ 114.048 WRITTEN CONSENT OF OWNER REQUIRED.
   No person shall paste, post, paint, print, nail or otherwise fasten any
handbill, sign, poster, advertisement or notice of any kind, or cause the same
to be done upon any private wall, roof, window, door, gate, fence, advertising
board or signboard or upon any other private structure or building, unless such
person is the owner, agent or lessee thereof, without the written consent of
the owner, agent or lessee of the wall, roof, window, door, fence, gate,
advertising board, signboard or other private structure, building or private
grounds.
(Prior Code, § 114.048) Penalty, see §
10.99
§ 114.049 LEGAL NOTICES.
   Nothing in this subchapter contained shall be construed to apply to the
posting of legal notices by public officers in the performance of a public
duty, in the manner and in the place prescribed by law.
(Prior Code, § 114.049)
§ 114.050 CONSENT OF CITY AUTHORITIES.
   No person shall paste, post, paint, print, nail or otherwise fasten any
handbill, sign, poster, advertisement or notice of any kind whatsoever, or
cause the same to be done, on any curbstone, flagstone or any portion or part
of any sidewalk, pole, telephone pole, hydrant, bridge, pier or upon any
structure, within the limits of any street in the city, except as may be
required by the ordinances of the city, without the express consent of the city
authorities.
(Prior Code, § 114.050) Penalty, see §
10.99
DISTRIBUTION OF HANDBILLS AND
SAMPLES REQUIRING LICENSE
§ 114.065 LICENSE REQUIRED.
   No person, firm or corporation shall distribute, or cause to be distributed
indiscriminately to the public, any cards, circulars, handbills, samples of
merchandise or any advertising matter whatsoever on any public street or
sidewalk or other public place in the city, or distribute or cause to be
distributed indiscriminately by leaving at stores, offices, houses or
residences in the city, any cards, circulars, handbills, samples of merchandise
or any advertising matter whatsoever without having first secured a license so
to do as required by the provisions of §§
114.065 to
114.069, inclusive; provided that, the provisions of this subchapter shall not
be construed to prohibit the sale of articles by licensed peddlers or the
peddling or sale of any article or publication that may carry or be accompanied
by advertising matter where a charge is made or a price paid for such article
or publication.
(Prior Code, § 114.065) Penalty, see §
10.99
§ 114.066 APPLICATION FOR LICENSE.
   Any person desiring to distribute any such cards, circulars, handbills,
samples of merchandise, or any other advertising matter whatsoever, or to cause
the same to be distributed by one or more individuals as distributors, shall
make application in writing to the City Clerk for a license so to do, which
application shall set forth a general description of the cards, circulars,
handbills, samples of merchandise or advertising matter which it is proposed to
distribute and the name of the applicant and the name or names of the
individual or individuals who are to make the actual distribution of such
cards, circulars, handbills, samples of merchandise or advertising matter. No
license shall be issued to any but a person of good character. The Chief of
Police of the city shall make or cause to be made an investigation into the
character of each applicant as well as the character of each individual who is
to be engaged in the actual distribution of such cards, circulars, handbills,
samples of merchandise or advertising matter and shall report the results
thereof to the City Clerk before any such license shall be issued.
(Prior Code, § 114.066)
§ 114.067 LICENSE FEE; EXPIRATION.
   The license required under the terms of §§
114.065 to
114.069, inclusive, may be issued on a yearly basis in which event the fee
shall be $50 or it may be issued for a period of one day, in which event the
license fee shall be $4. All licenses issued on a yearly basis shall expire on
April 30 next after the issuance thereof. The fee for any license issued on a
yearly basis, but for a period less than one year shall be reduced pro rata.
(Prior Code, § 114.067)
§ 114.068 REPORT OF CHANGE IN PERSONNEL.
   Any person to whom a license may be issued hereunder on a yearly basis shall
report in writing to the City Clerk as often as the circumstances may require,
any change or changes in the personnel of the individual or individuals making
the actual distribution of any such cards, circulars, handbills, samples of
merchandise or advertising matter. No individuals of questionable character
shall be permitted to act as such distributors.
(Prior Code, § 114.068)
§ 114.069 PERMITTED HOURS OF DISTRIBUTION.
   No cards, circulars, handbills, samples of merchandise or advertising matter
shall be distributed within the limits of the city, except between the hours of
6:00 a.m. and 7:00 p.m. and they shall not be distributed in such manner as to
litter any public street or sidewalk or any other public place in the city, nor
shall they be distributed in such manner as to become a public nuisance. The
distribution indiscriminately of any such cards, circulars, handbills, samples
of merchandise or advertising matter by leaving the same at stores, offices,
houses or residences in the city, shall be accomplished without undue
molestation of the occupants of such stores, offices, houses or residences.
(Prior Code, § 114.069)
§ 114.070 EXCEPTIONS.
   No provisions of this subchapter shall not apply to political or religious
speech or to newspaper or magazine solicitors.
(Prior Code, § 114.070)

FOOD DELIVERIES
§ 115.001 LICENSE REQUIRED.
   No person shall use or permit the use of any vehicle, including wagons and
motor vehicles and vehicles propelled by human power, for the storage or
carrying of any meat, poultry, fish, lard, vegetables, bread or bakery
products, or any other provisions intended for human consumption, excluding
milk, butter and cheese, in the city for the purpose of delivering any such
foodstuffs to any place in the city for the use and consumption or for resale
in the city, unless a license for the vehicle is secured and the provisions of
this subchapter are fully complied with.
(Prior Code, § 115.001) Penalty, see §
115.999
§ 115.002 APPLICATION; FEES.
   Any person desiring to use or permit the use of any vehicle for the purposes
set forth in §
115.001 of this chapter shall make application to the City Clerk for a license.
The application shall set forth the name and address of the owner of the
vehicle or vehicles for which the license or licenses are sought, the name or
names of the persons from whom the deliveries are made, and the nature of the
goods carried. The City Clerk shall issue the licenses and shall give to the
Health Commissioner a list of all licenses issued. The annual license fee for
each of the vehicles shall be $30 per year. All licenses shall expire April 30
next after the issuance. The fee for any license issued for a period of less
than one year shall be reduced pro rata.
(Prior Code, § 115.002)
§ 115.003 EXEMPTIONS.
   No license fee shall be required for any vehicle used to deliver foodstuffs
from any establishment which is licensed and inspected as a retail food
establishment in the city, nor shall any license fee be required for any
vehicle for which a peddler’s license has been issued by the city. However, all
provisions of this subchapter, other than that providing for the payment of a
fee, shall be complied with in regard to the vehicles.
(Prior Code, § 115.003)
§ 115.004 REGULATIONS.
   All vehicles shall be kept in a clean and sanitary condition and shall be
thoroughly cleaned each day that they are used. No person shall permit stale
food, decaying matter or any other waste or material to accumulate in or on any
vehicle while it is used. If foodstuffs not in covered containers or not
adequately protected in wrappings are transported in any vehicle, the goods
shall be carried in a portion or compartment of the vehicle which is screened
and protected against dust and insects.
(Prior Code, § 115.004) Penalty, see §
115.999
§ 115.005 INSPECTION.
   It shall be the duty of the Health Commissioner to make or cause to be made
inspections necessary to ensure compliance with the provisions of this
subchapter.
(Prior Code, § 115.005)
BAKERIES
§ 115.020 LICENSE REQUIRED.
   No person shall establish, maintain or operate any bakery in the city
without having been licensed by the city.
(Prior Code, § 115.020) Penalty, see §
115.999
§ 115.021 APPLICATION.
   Any person desiring to establish, maintain or operate a bakery shall make
application to the City Clerk for a license. The application shall set forth
the name and place of residence of the applicant together with the location of
the place for which the license is desired. The applicant shall pay a license
fee to the City Clerk.
(Prior Code, § 115.021)
§ 115.022 LICENSE FEE.
   The license fee to be paid to the City Clerk by the applicant shall be $50
per year. The license shall expire on April 30 following the date of its
issuance. If the license is issued for less than one year, the amount of the
license shall be reduced pro rata.
(Prior Code, § 115.022) (Ord. 1669, passed 4-14-1952; Ord. 2320, passed 3-23-
1976)
§ 115.023 SANITATION.
   All bakeries shall be conducted in a clean and sanitary manner and the
license of any bakery may be revoked if, upon examination by the Commissioner
of Health, the bakery is found to be in an unsanitary location or is conducted
in an unsanitary manner.
(Prior Code, § 115.023) Penalty, see §
115.999
FOOD DISPENSERS
§ 115.035 DEFINITION.
   For the purpose of this subchapter, the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
   FOOD DISPENSER. Any person, firm or corporation that keeps for sale, and
serves to the general public, for consumption on the premises, or on the
sidewalk or public way contiguous to the premises, any articles of food or
drink for human consumption. Restaurants, ordinaries, coffee houses, ice cream
parlors, lunch rooms, tea rooms, lunch stands, refreshment stands, box lunch
deliveries, luncheonettes, cafeterias and retail drug stores serving counter
lunches and drinks shall be included among FOOD DISPENSERS.
   SERVES. The placing of the food for the convenience of the patron into any
cup, glass, cone, dish, plate or other receptacle from which the patron may
conveniently “consume it”.
(Prior Code, § 115.035)
§ 115.036 LICENSE REQUIRED; APPLICATION.
   No person shall conduct or operate the business of food dispenser without
first having obtained a license. Written application, which shall conform to
the general requirements of this subchapter relating to applications for
licenses, shall be made to the City Clerk. The application shall contain the
name and residence of the applicant and, if the applicant is a firm, of each
member of the firm. If the applicant is a corporation, the application shall
contain the names and residences of its principal officers. The application
shall contain such further information as may be required by the Commissioner
of Health in order to inform the Commissioner fully of the size and nature of
the place to be used for the purposes of the business and the conditions,
equipment and facilities for conducting the business therein, the health of
persons to be employed and the regulations and facilities provided for them.
(Prior Code, § 115.036) Penalty, see §
115.999
§ 115.037 OUTDOOR DINING; LICENSE.
   Any food dispenser may apply for a permit for outdoor dining or café seating
pursuant to the following requirements and conditions. No event center events
or similar activities will be permitted outdoor dining or café seating.
   (A)   Generally. Subject to approval by the city, outdoor dining or café
seating may be made up of a combination of sidewalk space, private parking,
city parking, and on-street parking subject to the below conditions. Outdoor
seating cannot exceed 50% of a food dispenser’s total seating capacity, and no
more than 25% of a food dispenser’s parking facilities may be converted to
outdoor dining.
   (B)   Conditions.
      (1)   Sidewalk dining or café seating is subject to the following
conditions.
         (a)   The food dispenser otherwise conforms with current city zoning
code.
         (b)   The sidewalk is wide enough for sidewalk dining or café seating.
         (c)   A five-foot minimum clear zone is provided for pedestrian
traffic. A reduction to the clear zone can be requested with a detailed
justification but will require additional review and processing time.
         (d)   Fencing is optional. Pavement demarcations are required for all
outdoor dining or café seating areas. These must be provided prior to operation
of any sidewalk dining or café seating, and are subject to inspection and
approval by the city.
      (2)   Seating in private or city parking lots is subject to the following
conditions.
         (a)   The outdoor seating or café dining will not impair the normal,
safe and effective operation of a permanent use on the same site.
         (b)   The outdoor seating or café dining will not significantly impact
public health, safety or convenience, or create traffic hazards or congestion,
or otherwise interrupt or interfere with the normal conduct or uses and
activities in the vicinity.
         (c)   The outdoor seating or café dining will not be materially
detrimental to the surrounding uses in terms of traffic, noise and other
external effects.
      (3)   General conditions for all outdoor or café seating.
         (a)   The outdoor seating or café dining must be immediately adjacent
to the food dispenser location.
         (b)   Outdoor seating or café dining conducted in a city or private
parking facility shall not occupy or remove from availability more than 25% of
the spaces required for the permanent use.
         (c)   Each site occupied by outdoor or café dining must provide or
have available enough parking and vehicular maneuvering area for customers or
other users.
         (d)   Each site occupied by outdoor or café dining shall be left free
of debris, litter or other evidence of the outdoor or café dining upon
completion and removal of the use.
         (e)   All materials, structures and products related to the outdoor or
café dining must be removed from the premises following expiration of the
permit.
         (f)   Additional conditions may be established as necessary and as
required by the city to ensure land use compatibility and to minimize potential
impacts on nearby uses. These include, but are not limited to, time and
frequency of operation, temporary arrangements for parking and traffic
circulation, requirement for screening or enclosure, and guarantees for site
restoration and cleanup following outdoor or café dining.
         (g)   If multiple applicants would like to convert parking to outdoor
or café seating, the city shall evaluate potential for shared space between
businesses.
         (h)   All areas temporarily repurposed for outdoor seating or café
dining shall only be used with the understanding that the city may require
immediate access to utilities or other infrastructure for the purpose of
maintenance and emergencies.
   (C)   Permits. Food dispensers wanting to provide outdoor or café dining
must submit a temporary outdoor dining permit application from the city, which
includes providing the city with a sketch of the proposed outdoor or café
dining area. Permits for outdoor or café dining are valid from May 1 through
October 31 in any given year. The permit fee for outdoor or café dining is $100
per year.
(Ord. 2021-015, passed 6-22-2021)
§ 115.038 LICENSE FEE; TERM.
   (A)   The annual license fee for a restaurant shall be $100. However, the
license fee for a restaurant with a maximum seating capacity of less than 50
persons shall be $50 per year. The annual license fee for all other food
dispensers shall be $50; provided that, in each case where the applicant for
the license as a food dispenser is a person holding a Class A retailer’s liquor
license under the provisions of
Ch. 111 of this code of ordinances, the license fee to be charged shall be $25.
Where the holder of such Class A retailer’s liquor license is engaged in the
business of serving meals to the public regularly each day in the manner
customarily followed by restaurants, the license fee shall be $50.
   (B)   A food dispenser’s license shall expire on April 30 next following its
issuance. License fees payable upon the initial issuance of a license shall be
reduced in proportion to the number of full quarters of the license year which
have elapsed prior to the date on which the license is issued.
(Prior Code, § 115.037) (Ord. 1669, passed 4-14-1952; Ord. 2306, passed 3-23-
1976)
§ 115.039 INSPECTION.
   Before any license is issued by the Commissioner of Health shall cause an
inspection to be made of the premises to be occupied by the applicant as a food
dispenser, the equipment contained therein, the persons to be employed therein,
the sanitary and hygienic features and conditions, and all other matters
relating to the business which the Commissioner considers it is necessary or
proper to inquire into from the standpoint of health and sanitation. If the
Commissioner of Health is satisfied from the inspection that the place where
the business is to be conducted is in a sanitary condition and a fit and proper
place for the business and that all the provisions of this subchapter relating
to the conduct of the business have been observed, the Commissioner shall
approve the application, and thereupon, upon the payment of the license fee
herein provided, the Mayor may issue a license to the applicant to conduct the
business at the place during the year for which the license is issued. The
Mayor may revoke the license at any time by notice in writing whenever it shall
appear to the Mayor’s satisfaction from the recommendation of the Commissioner
of Health or otherwise that the licensee has violated the provisions of any
state or city law relating to the carrying on of the business of food dispenser
and has failed to correct the violation upon due notice from the Commissioner
of Health. In addition to the preliminary inspection herein provided for, the
Commissioner of Health shall cause periodical inspections to be made of the
place and personnel employed for the purpose of determining whether all the
requirements of this subchapter and the state health and sanitation laws are
being complied with. The periodical inspections shall be made with special
reference to the requirements of §
115.040 of this chapter.
(Prior Code, § 115.038) Penalty, see §
115.999
§ 115.040 REGULATION OF FOOD DISPENSERS.
   The conditions and regulations contained in §§
115.035 through
115.040 of this chapter shall be observed in all food dispensers’ places or
establishments.
(Prior Code, § 115.039) Penalty, see §
115.999
§ 115.041 DINING ROOM REQUIREMENTS.
   There shall be adequate light and ventilation; the walls, ceilings and
floors shall be clean and in good repair; tables, counters, shelves and other
furniture shall have clean surfaces, and be kept clean. All utensils, including
urns and containers for milk, cream, coffee and water shall be made of
materials that can be easily cleaned and disinfected. Foods during service
hours shall be handled or kept so that they are not exposed to contamination by
dirt, flies or vermin, or promiscuous handling by patrons.
(Prior Code, § 115.040) Penalty, see §
115.999
§ 115.042 KITCHEN REQUIREMENTS.
   The kitchen shall have adequate light and ventilation, and the air flow
shall always be from the dining room through the kitchen. The discharge from
kitchen fans shall always be through a duct to a point above the roof line to
protect the occupants of the building in which the establishment is located or
adjoining buildings from nuisance. Ranges, refrigerators and other bulky
equipment should be so arranged as not to obstruct the light and ventilation.
Tables for clean and dirty dishes and food shall be so arranged that the dirty
dishes will be as far removed from the food rack and clean dishes as may be
possible. Ranges shall be hooded so that the cooking odors may be effectually
carried off by a stack or an exhaust fan or a skylight immediately above. The
walls and ceilings shall be preferably impervious, in good repair and kept
clean at all times. The floors and walls should be rat-proof and vermin-proof.
Ranges, steam tables, shelves, racks, blocks, tables or other machinery or
furniture used in mixing, cutting, grinding, cooking or otherwise preparing the
foods for service shall be of such material and construction that they may be
kept scrupulously clean at all times.
(Prior Code, § 115.041) Penalty, see §
115.999
§ 115.043 REFRIGERATORS.
   (A)   Refrigerators shall be lined with impervious non-absorbent material
and adequately drained by indirect or broken connection with the sewer.
   (B)   There shall be separate compartments for keeping food materials which
may unfavorably affect each other if kept together.
   (C)   Scrupulous cleanliness shall be maintained at all times.
(Prior Code, § 115.042) Penalty, see §
115.999
§ 115.044 PLUMBING.
   (A)   There shall be adequate plumbing facilities so that there is a
sufficient supply of running hot and cold water for all washing purposes, and
all fixtures, such as sinks, wash basins and the like, must be adequately
trapped, vented and revented, and properly connected to the sewer.
   (B)   All sinks in which greasy pots or dishes are washed must be connected
to a catchbasin or be equipped with an approved waterjacket grease trap.
(Prior Code, § 115.043) Penalty, see §
115.999
§ 115.045 EMPLOYEES; CLEANLINESS AND HEALTH.
   All employees shall be clean in person and in clothing, and no person
afflicted with any contagious or infectious disease in communicable form and no
human carrier of b. diphtheria, b. Typhosus, b. dysenteriae, b. enteritidis, b.
paratyphosus, a. or b. amoebic dysentery shall be employed in or about the
preparing, handling, cooking or serving of foodstuffs, or in the washing of the
dishes or other utensils.
(Prior Code, § 115.044) Penalty, see §
115.999
§ 115.046 STORAGE OF FOODSTUFFS.
   All store rooms or other rooms directly connected with the establishment
shall be clean, dry and kept in such a condition as not to affect unfavorably
the foodstuffs used or the health of the employees or of the public. Yards,
cellars or other areas directly connected with, or in close proximity to, the
establishment shall be kept clean.
(Prior Code, § 115.045) Penalty, see §
115.999
§ 115.047 DISHES AND EATING UTENSILS TO BE CLEANED.
   (A)   Glasses, cups, dishes, knives, forks, spoons and other eating and
drinking utensils which are used more than once in any food dispensing
establishment or any similar establishment shall be thoroughly washed and
cleansed in such a way as to remove completely all visible foreign matter by
either of the following methods:
      (1)   By mechanical dish washing machine which have a direct connection
to hot water supply and which spray a fresh supply of hot rinse water direct on
all sides of dishes and eating and drinking utensils;
      (2)   By handwashing, which shall be done in warm water containing soap
or other effective cleansing agent and followed by rinsing in clean boiling
water of a temperature not below 170°F for at least one minute, followed by
draining; provided, however, that, in lieu of such rinsing in boiling water,
such dishes and utensils may be immersed for at least one minute in clean
water, such quantity as to yield approximately 100 parts per million of
available chlorine (one-half ounce of a solution of chlorinated soda per gallon
of wash water). The amount of available chlorine in such rinse water at no time
shall be less than 35 parts per million, and the water shall be kept clean at
all times; or
      (3)   By handwashing which shall be done in clean warm water containing
an inorganic cleansing agent to which has been added a chlorine disinfectant in
such quantity as to yield approximately 200 parts per million of available
chlorine. The water shall be changed when dirty. The washing mixture shall at
no time contain less than 35 parts per million of available chlorine.
   (B)   No such glass, cup, dish, knife, fork, spoon or other eating or
drinking vessel or utensil, after use by one patron in eating or drinking,
shall be offered or permitted to be used by any other patron without such
glass, cup, dish, knife, fork, spoon or other eating or drinking vessel or
utensil having been first thoroughly washed and cleansed by either of the
foregoing methods.
(Prior Code, § 115.046) Penalty, see §
115.999
§ 115.048 POISONOUS SUBSTANCES NOT PERMITTED TO COME INTO CONTACT WITH
FOODSTUFFS.
   No person operating, maintaining or conducting any hotel, club, restaurant,
coffee house, lunchroom or other eating place wherein food is served to the
public, shall use any ingredient or substance containing any sodium cyanide,
potassium cyanide, oxalic acid, mercuric compound or other poisonous
substances, for the cleaning of nickel, copper, silverware or silver-plated
ware, and other articles or utensils used for the service or preparation of
food or foodstuffs.
(Prior Code, § 115.047) Penalty, see §
115.999
§ 115.049 FOOD TO BE ADEQUATELY PROTECTED.
   All food which is received and which is intended to be used and prepared for
human consumption upon being received by any person shall be adequately
protected from dust, flies, vermin and other insects.
(Prior Code, § 115.048) Penalty, see §
115.999
§ 115.050 PLACE WHERE FOOD SERVED TO BE CLEAN.
   The room or place where food is sold or served for human consumption shall
be kept in a clean and sanitary condition.
(Prior Code, § 115.049) Penalty, see §
115.999
§ 115.051 CLOTHING OF EMPLOYEES.
   All persons who are engaged in preparing meals to be sold at such places
shall wear suitable clothing which shall be clean and of a washable character
or nature and used for that purpose only.
(Prior Code, § 115.050) Penalty, see §
115.999
§ 115.052 PREMISES TO BE FREE FROM VERMIN AND HARMFUL MATERIAL.
   Every such place shall be kept free from rats, mice and vermin and free from
matter of a deleterious nature.
(Prior Code, § 115.051) Penalty, see §
115.999
§ 115.053 RECEPTACLES FOR GARBAGE.
   (A)   Every person owning or controlling any place where more than 20 guests
or boarders are fed daily shall cause all offal, table refuse, shells and
animal or vegetable matter commonly known and described as garbage, to be
placed in proper metallic cans, which shall be practically air- and water-tight
and shall cause all such substances deposited in such cans or receptacles to be
removed daily from the premises and to be disposed of either by burning in a
properly constructed crematory which shall have been approved by the
Commissioner of Health or by dumping the same at any dumping ground or place
where garbage is dumped or disposed of by the city. The removal and disposition
of such substances shall be done by such person at such person’s own expense
solely, and in accordance with the provisions of this subchapter, and the
directions or rules of the Commissioner of Health relating to the disposition
and removal of such substances.
   (B)   All garbage and refuse shall be kept in such manner and at such places
and the same will not become a nuisance to the public. The use of wooden boxes
or barrels for the storage of garbage or refuse will not be permitted; except
that, wooden barrels which are washed regularly may be used for the storage of
grease for soap stock.
(Prior Code, § 115.052) Penalty, see §
115.999
§ 115.054 FOOD HANDLING AND SERVING METHODS.
   All employees in such establishment and all persons handling or serving food
therein are prohibited from handling butter intended to be used for foods in
such places in a manner which causes their hands to come in contact therewith
and from picking up glasses, cups or mixers with their fingers inserted
therein, and from wiping dishes with soiled napkins or aprons or with napkins
or aprons that were previously used for any purpose and not relaundered since
last used. No bakery goods shall be exposed for the purpose of exhibiting same
in such places unless adequately protected against insects of all kinds and
contamination by dust or handling by patrons. Such places shall not be so
dusted or swept that dust will settle on food that is exposed. Dry sweeping in
such places is prohibited and, if indulged in, shall subject both the
proprietor or manager and the employee who actually does the sweeping to the
penalty herein prescribed.
(Prior Code, § 115.053) Penalty, see §
115.999
§ 115.055 SCREENS REQUIRED.
   Every such establishment shall be kept reasonably free from flies, and the
doors, windows and other openings of every such place shall, from April 15 to
November 15 in each year, be fitted with wire window screens and self-closing
wire screen doors.
(Prior Code, § 115.054) Penalty, see §
115.999
§ 115.056 ENFORCEMENT.
   (A)   It shall be the duty of the Commissioner of Health to enforce the
provisions of this subchapter, and the Commissioner is authorized and empowered
from time to time to inspect and examine all retail food establishments, as
defined herein, for the purpose of ascertaining whether such sections and all
ordinances of the city and laws of state, relative to retail food
establishments, are being complied with.
   (B)   It shall be the duty of every owner or operator of a retail food
establishment to permit such inspections to be made and, when required, to
furnish samples of any foods kept, sold, offered for sale or served in any such
establishment.
   (C)   The samples shall be examined or analyzed by or under the direction of
the Commissioner of Health and a record of each such examination or analysis
shall be made and kept on file in the Commissioner’s office.
(Prior Code, § 115.055)
DRIVE-IN RESTAURANTS
§ 115.070 ACTS PROHIBITED.
   (A)   No person while on or adjacent to the premises of any drive-in
restaurant within the city limits shall race the motor of any car or suddenly
start or stop any motor of any car or make or cause to be made any loud or
unusual noise.
   (B)   No person parked on the premises of a drive-in restaurant shall blow
or cause to be blown any automobile horn or motorcycle horn at any time while
so parked.
(Prior Code, § 115.070) Penalty, see §
115.999
§ 115.071 INTOXICATING LIQUOR PROHIBITED ON PREMISES.
   No patron or other person on the premises of a drive-in restaurant, whether
in or out of a motor vehicle, shall drink any beer or other intoxicating liquor
or at any time to have in his or her possession any open bottle, can or other
receptacle containing beer or alcoholic liquor.
(Prior Code, § 115.071) (Ord. 2035, passed 6-12-1967) Penalty, see §
115.999
§ 115.072 LOITERING PROHIBITED.
   (A)   No group of three or more persons shall congregate or loiter at any
location on the premises of a drive-in restaurant other than in the restaurant
building or in a parked motor vehicle.
   (B)   No person shall drive a motor vehicle onto the premises of a
restaurant and then from the premises without parking the vehicle unless there
is a lack of available parking space thereon.
(Prior Code, § 115.072) (Ord. 2035, passed 6-12-1967) Penalty, see §
115.999
§ 115.073 LEAVING UNOCCUPIED VEHICLES PROHIBITED.
   No person shall leave any unoccupied motor vehicle on any restaurant parking
lot and leave the premises for more than ten minutes, except with the knowledge
and consent of the proprietor of the restaurant.
(Prior Code, § 115.073) (Ord. 2035, passed 6-12-1967) Penalty, see §
115.999
§ 115.074 NOTICE TO BE POSTED.
   It shall be the duty of the restaurant operator or proprietor who furnishes
parking to patrons to post on the premises in a conspicuous location, in words
of not less than one inch type, at least one sign bearing the following legend:
 
CRUISING IN OR CONGREGATING OR LOITERING OUTSIDE OF A MOTOR VEHICLE IS
UNLAWFUL. NO UNOCCUPIED VEHICLE MAY BE LEFT ON THE PREMISES FOR MORE THAN 10
MINUTES WITHOUT THE CONSENT OF THE RESTAURANT OPERATOR.
 
(Prior Code, § 115.074) (Ord. 2035, passed 6-12-1967)
AUTOMATIC FOOD VENDING MACHINES
§ 115.085 DEFINITIONS.
   For the purpose of this subchapter, the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
   AUTOMATIC FOOD VENDING MACHINE. Any mechanical container or device used for
the sale of any article of food, the operation of which is governed or
controlled by the deposit of a coin or token.
   FOOD. Any cooked or uncooked article of food, drink, condiment or confection
used for or intended to be used for human consumption.
   MULTIPLE AUTOMATIC FOOD VENDING MACHINE. An automatic food vending machine
equipped with or containing a plural number of magazines, columns, shelves or
other compartments for the holding of food.
   SINGLE AUTOMATIC FOOD VENDING MACHINE. An automatic food vending machine
which is equipped with or containing one magazine, column, shelter or other
compartment for the holding of food.
(Prior Code, § 115.085) (Ord. 1748, passed 1-3-1956)
§ 115.086 LICENSE REQUIRED.
   (A)   No person shall deliver or install any automatic food vending machine
within the city without having obtained a license.
   (B)   No person shall install, keep, maintain or use, or permit the
installation, keeping, maintenance or use, upon such person’s premises of any
automatic food vending machine for which a license has not been issued for the
current year.
(Prior Code, § 115.086) (Ord. 1748, passed 1-23-1956) Penalty, see §
115.999
§ 115.087 APPLICATION FOR LICENSE.
   (A)   Any person desiring a license for an automatic food vending machine or
machines shall make application in writing to the City Clerk.
   (B)   The application shall set forth the number of automatic food vending
machines intended to be installed, the location at which each is to be
installed, and a description of each.
   (C)   The description shall contain the manufacturer’s name, the make and
factory number, whether a single or multiple machine, and the monetary value of
the coin or coins used to operate the machine.
   (D)   The application shall also set forth further information required by
the Health Commissioner concerning the type or types of machines and the kind
or kinds of food to be dispensed therefrom.
   (E)   Before any license is issued, the Health Commissioner shall cause an
inspection to be made to determine the character and fitness of the machine or
machines from the standpoint of insuring protection of the food from improper
handling, dust, dirt, flies, vermin or other contamination.
(Prior Code, § 115.087) (Ord. 1748, passed 1-23-1956; Ord. 1748, passed 6-12-
1967)
§ 115.088 LICENSE FEE.
   Every owner of an automatic food vending machine installed or maintained
within the city shall pay an annual license fee of $50 and, in addition
thereto, for each automatic food vending machine installed or maintained by
such person, annual license fees as prescribed in the following classes:
   (A)   Class “I”, single machines operated by the deposit of coins or tokens
of the monetary value of $0.01: $1;
   (B)   Class “II”, multiple machines operated by the deposit of coins or
tokens of the monetary value of $0.01: $1.50;
   (C)   Class “III”, single machines operated by the deposit of coins or
tokens of a monetary value from $0.02 to $0.05: $2;
   (D)   Class “IV”, multiple machines operated by the deposit of coins or
tokens of a monetary value from $0.02 to $0.05: $3;
   (E)   Class “V”, single machines operated by the deposit of coins or tokens
of a monetary value from $0.06 to $0.10: $3.50;
   (F)   Class “VI”, multiple machines operated by the deposit of coins or
tokens of a monetary value from $0.06 to $0.10: $5;
   (G)   Class “VII”, single machines operated by the deposit of coins or
tokens of a monetary value from $0.11 to $0.20: $10;
   (H)   Class “VIII”, multiple machines operated by the deposit of coins or
tokens of a monetary value from $0.11 to $0.20: $15;
   (I)   Class “DC”, single machines operated by the deposit of coins or tokens
of the monetary value over $0.20: $20; and
   (J)   Class “X”, multiple machines operated by the deposit of coins or
tokens of the monetary value over $0.20: $25.
(Prior Code, § 115.088) (Ord. 2337, passed 3-27-1976)
§ 115.089 REGULATIONS; INSPECTION.
   Before any license shall be issued, the Commissioner of Health shall cause
an inspection to be made to determine the character and fitness of the machine
or machines from the standpoint of ensuring protection of the food from
improper handling, dust, dirt, flies, vermin or other contamination. All
articles of food provided by means of automatic food vending machines shall be
clean, wholesome, free from taint, decay or infection and shall contain no
poisonous, deleterious or other injurious ingredients in kind and quantities so
as to render such articles injurious or detrimental to health. The Health
Commissioner shall make periodic inspections of all such machines and the
articles of food provided therefrom to assure compliance with all requirements
of this subchapter and other applicable ordinances.
(Prior Code, § 115.089) (Ord. 1748, passed 6-12-1967)
§ 115.090 EMBLEM TO BE KEPT WITH LICENSE.
   (A)   The City Clerk shall deliver with each automatic food vending; machine
license a sticker license emblem for each machine authorized to be kept or
installed under the license.
   (B)   The sticker shall bear appropriate information indicating the number
of the license and the year for which it is issued.
(Prior Code, § 115.090) (Ord. 1748, passed 6-12-1967)
§ 115.091 ADDITIONAL LICENSES.
   Upon the filing of a supplemental application and the payment of the
prescribed fees, a licensee shall be entitled to receive license emblems and
install additional machines at the location or locations designated for a
supplemental application.
(Prior Code, § 115.091) (Ord. 1748, passed 6-12-1967)
RETAIL FOOD STORES
§ 115.105 DEFINITIONS.
   For the purpose of this subchapter, the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
   RETAIL FOOD STORE. Any store, stand, booth, pavilion or other place of
business wherein there is sold or offered for sale at retail any article of
food, confection, condiment or drink used or intended for human consumption;
provided that, hotels, bakeries, food dispensers, peddlers and milk dealers,
who are especially licensed and defined by other city ordinances, shall not be
considered retail food stores for the purposes of this subchapter.
   SALE AT RETAIL. Any transfer of the ownership of or title to tangible
personal property to the purchaser for use or consumption, and not for resale
in any form as tangible personal property for a valuable consideration.
(Prior Code, § 115.105)
§ 115.106 LICENSE REQUIRED.
   No person, firm or corporation shall operate or maintain a retail food store
in the city without securing a license as hereinafter provided.
(Prior Code, § 115.106) Penalty, see §
115.999
§ 115.107 APPLICATION.
   Any person desiring to establish, maintain or operate a retail food store,
as defined in §
115.105 of this chapter, shall make application to the City Clerk for a license
to do so. The application shall contain the name and residence of the
applicant, the place at which it is intended or desired to carry on or conduct
the retail food store, a brief description of the commodities desired to be
sold, and any further information which may be required by the City Clerk in
keeping with the provisions of this subchapter.
(Prior Code, § 115.107)
§ 115.108 LICENSE FEE; TERM.
   (A)   The license fee to be paid by the applicant desiring to establish,
operate or maintain a retail food store shall be $50 per year.
   (B)   All licenses shall expire on April 30 following the date of issuance.
If issued for less than one year, the amount of the license fee shall be
reduced pro rata.
(Prior Code, § 115.108) (Ord. 1669, passed 4-14-1952; Ord. 2305, passed 3-23-
1976)
§ 115.109 SANITARY REQUIREMENTS.
   Every retail food store shall be conducted in a clean and sanitary manner
and shall at all times be subject to the inspection of the City Health
Commissioner. In all cases where perishable food is kept for sale, adequate
provision should be made for the refrigeration of perishable foods that require
refrigeration in order to keep them in a wholesome state. The premises of any
retail food store shall be protected as far as practicable against flies and
all manner of vermin. Spoiled or decayed food and any other refuse shall not be
allowed to accumulate in or about the premises, and all refuse containers shall
be of tight construction and furnished with adequate covers.
(Prior Code, § 115.109) Penalty, see §
115.999
§ 115.110 SUNDAY SALE RESTRICTION ON FRESH MEAT.
   In order to ensure inspection and prevent sale of unwholesome and tainted
meats, it shall be unlawful for any person to keep open or conduct any meat
market, or to expose or offer for sale therein any fresh meats between the
hours of 12:00 a.m. and 12:00 p.m. on Sundays.
(Prior Code, § 115.110) Penalty, see §
115.999
FOOD SERVICE SANITATION
§ 115.125 DEFINITIONS.
   For the purpose of this subchapter, the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
   ADULTERATED. The condition of a food:
      (1)   If it bears or contains any poisonous or deleterious substance in a
quantity which may render it injurious to health;
      (2)   If it bears or contains any added poisonous or deleterious
substance for which no safe tolerance has been established by regulation, or in
excess of such tolerance if one has been established;
      (3)   If it consists in whole or in part of any filthy, putrid or
decomposed substance, or if it is otherwise unfit for human consumption;
      (4)   If it has been processed, prepared, packed or held under unsanitary
conditions, whereby, it may be become contaminated with filth or, whereby, it
may have been rendered injurious to health;
      (5)   If it is whole or in part the product of a diseased animal, or an
animal which has died otherwise than by slaughter; or
      (6)   If the containers are composed in whole or in part of any poisonous
or deleterious substance which may render the contents injurious to health.
   ADEQUATE. Acceptable or sufficient as determined by Health Authority.
   APPROVED. Acceptable to the Health Officer based on his or her determination
as to conformance with appropriate standards and good public health practice.
   AUTHORIZED REPRESENTATIVE. The legally designated Health Authority of the
city and shall include those persons designated by the Health Authority to
enforce the provisions of this subchapter.
   CLOSED. Fitted together snugly leaving no openings large enough to permit
the entrance of vermin.
   CORROSION-RESISTANCE MATERIAL. A material which maintains it original
surface characteristics under prolonged influence of the food, cleaning
compounds and sanitizing solutions which may contact it.
   EASILY CLEANABLE. Readily accessible and of such material and finish, and so
fabricated that residue may be completely removed by normal cleaning methods.
   EMPLOYEE. Any person working in a food service establishment or retail food
store who transports food or food containers, who engages in food preparation,
packaging or service, or who comes in contact with any food utensils or
equipment.
   EQUIPMENT. All stoves, ranges, hoods, meat blocks, tables, counters,
refrigerators, sinks, dishwashing machines, steamtables and similar items,
other than utensils, used in the operation of a food service establishment or
retail food store.
   FOOD. Any raw, cooked or processed edible substance, beverage or ingredient
used or intended for use or for sale in whole or in part for human consumption.
   FOOD CONTACT SURFACES. Those surfaces of equipment and utensils with which
food normally comes in contact, and those surfaces with which food may come in
contact and drain back onto surfaces normally in contact with food.
   FOOD PROCESSING ESTABLISHMENT. A commercial establishment in which food is
processed or otherwise prepared and packaged for human consumption.
   FOOD SERVICE ESTABLISHMENT. Any fixed or mobile restaurant, coffee shop,
cafeteria, short-order café, luncheonette, grill, tearoom, sandwich shop, soda
fountain, tavern, bar, cocktail lounge, night club, roadside stand, industrial-
feeding establishment, private, public or non-profit organization or
institution which is routinely serving food; any catering kitchen, commissary
or similar place in which food or drink is prepared for sale or for service on
the premises or elsewhere; and any other eating or drinking establishment or
operation where food is served or provided for the public with or without
charge.
   HEALTH AUTHORITY.
      (1)   The Aldermen of the city who compose the Health Committee, and the
Mayor.
      (2)   The person or persons who have been designated by the Mayor and
City Council to administer the affairs of the City Health Department.
   KITCHENWARE. All multi-use utensils other than tableware used in the
storage, preparation, conveying or serving of food.
   LAW. State and local statutes, ordinances and regulations.
   LICENSE HOLDER. An individual, a firm, partnership, company, corporation,
trustee, association or public or private entity who is directly or indirectly
responsible for the operation of a food service establishment or retail food
store.
   MISBRANDED. The presence of any written, printed or graphic matter, upon or
accompanying food or containers of food, which is false or misleading, or which
violates any applicable state or local labeling requirements.
   MOBILE FOOD SERVICE ESTABLISH- MENT. Any food service establishment capable
of being moved from location to location, or without a fixed location.
   PACKAGED. Bottled, canned, cartoned or securely wrapped.
   PERISHABLE FOOD. Any food of such type or in such condition as may spoil.
   PERMANENT FOOD SERVICE ESTABLISHMENT OR RETAIL FOOD STORE. Any food service
establishment or retail food store which operates at a fixed location for a
period of time exceeding 14 days.
   PERSON IN CHARGE. The individual present in a food service establishment who
is the supervisor of the food service establishment at the time.
   POTENTIALLY HAZARDOUS FOOD. Any perishable food which consists in whole, or
in part, of milk or milk products, eggs, meat, poultry, fish, shellfish or
other ingredients capable of supporting rapid and progressive growth of
infectious or toxigenic micro-organisms.
   RETAIL FOOD STORE. Retail grocery, meat market, poultry market, fish market,
fresh fruit and vegetable market, confectionery, nut store, retail bakery or
any other establishment, whether fixed or movable, where food, intended for
human consumption, off the premises, is prepared, handled, transported, sold or
offered for sale at retail.
   SAFE TEMPERATURES. As applied to potentially hazardous food, shall mean
temperatures of 45°F or below, and 140°F or above. As applied to frozen
perishable foods, SAFE TEMPERATURES shall be -0°F or below, except for a
variation of 15°F during transit, unloading or defrosting during a mechanical
defrosting cycle. Temperatures shall be determined by measurement of the actual
product temperature or the ambient air temperature in the storage device.
   SANITIZING.
      (1)   Effective bactericidal treatment by a process that destroys micro-
organisms, including pathogens.
      (2)   Effective bactericidal treatment is demonstrated by an average
plate count per tableware utensil surface examined of not more than 100
colonies, or not more than 12-1/2 colonies per square inch of equipment and
utensils surfaces examined other than tableware in accordance with procedures
detailed in Public Health Service Publication No. 1631 (Procedure for the
Bacteriological Examination of Food Utensils and or Flood Equipment Surfaces).
   SEALED. Free of cracks or other opening which permit entry or passage or
moisture.
   SINGLE SERVICE ARTICLES. Cups, containers, lids or closures; plates, knives,
forks, spoons, stirrers, paddles, straws, place mats, napkins, doilies,
scrapping material and all similar articles which are constructed wholly in
part from paper, paperboard, molded pulp, foil, wood, plastic, synthetic or
other readily destructible materials, and which are intended by the
manufacturer and generally recognized by the public as for one usage only, then
to be discarded.
   TABLEWARE. All multi-use eating and drinking utensils, including flatware
(knives, forks and spoons).
   TEMPORARY FOOD SERVICE ESTAB- LISHMENT. Any food service establishment which
operates at a fixed location for a term not exceed two weeks, in connection
with a fair, carnival, circus, public exhibition or similar transitory
gathering.
   TEMPORARY RETAIL FOOD STORES. Any retail food store which operates at a
fixed location for a temporary period of time not to exceed two weeks.
   UTENSILS. Any tableware and kitchenware used in the storage, preparation,
conveying or serving of food.
   WHOLESOME. In sound condition, clean, free from adulteration, and otherwise
suitable for use as human food.
(Prior Code, § 115.125)
§ 115.126 ADOPTION OF HEALTH REGULATIONS.
   In addition to those provisions set forth in the city code of ordinances for
food sanitation, the city hereby adopts by reference the provisions set forth
in the State Department of Public Health’s Food Service Sanitation Code, 77
Ill. Adm. Code Part 750.
(Prior Code, § 115.126)
§ 115.127 LICENSE REQUIRED; NON- TRANSFERABLE.
   (A)   It shall be unlawful for any person to operate a food service
establishment or retail food store within the city, who does not possesses a
valid license issued to him or her by the City Clerk. Only a person who
complies with the requirements of this chapter shall be entitled to receive and
retail such a license. Licenses shall not be transferable from one person to
another person or place.
   (B)   A valid license shall be posted in a conspicuous place in every food
service and retail food establishment.
(Prior Code, § 115.127) Penalty, see §
115.999
§ 115.128 LICENSE EXPIRATION.
   Licenses for permanent food service establishments and retail food stores
shall expire on April 30 next following the date of issuance. Licenses for
temporary food service establishments and temporary retail food stores shall be
issued for a period of time not to exceed 14 days.
(Prior Code, § 115.128)
§ 115.129 ISSUANCE OF LICENSE.
   (A)   Any person desiring to operate a food service establishment or retail
food store or to renew an expired license shall make written application for a
permit on forms provided by the Health Authority. Such application shall
include: the applicant’s full name and post office address and whether such
applicant is an individual, firm or corporation; and, if a partnership, the
names of partners, together with their addresses shall be included; the
location and type of the proposed food service establishment or retail food
store; and the signature of the applicant or applicants. If the application is
for a temporary food service establishment or temporary retail food store, it
shall also include the inclusive dates of the proposed operation.
   (B)   Upon receipt of such an application, the Health Officer shall make an
inspection of the establishment to determine compliance with the provisions of
this subchapter. When inspection reveals that the applicable requirements of
this subchapter have been met, a license shall be issued to the applicant by
the Health Authority.
(Prior Code, § 115.129)
§ 115.130 RENEWAL OF LICENSE.
   Whenever the inspection for renewal of a license reveals serious or repeated
violations of this subchapter, the license will not be issued and the Health
Authority shall notify the applicant immediately thereof. Such notice shall
state the reasons for not renewing the permit. Such notice shall also state
that an opportunity for a hearing shall be provided for the applicant at a time
and place designated by the Health Authority. Such hearing shall be scheduled
not later than ten days from the date of the notice. The notice referred to in
this delivered to the applicant in person by the Health Authority.
(Prior Code, § 115.130)
§ 115.131 SUSPENSION OF LICENSES.
   (A)   Licenses may be suspended temporarily by the Health Authority for
failure of the license holder to comply with the requirements of this
subchapter. Whenever a license holder or operator has failed to comply with any
notice issued under the provisions of this subchapter, the license holder or
operator shall be notified in writing that the permit is, upon service of the
notice, immediately suspended and that an opportunity for a hearing will be
provided if a written request for a hearing is filed with the Health Authority
by the license holder.
   (B)   (1)   Upon suspension of the license, the license shall be removed
from the establishment by the Health Authority and returned to the Health
Department.
      (2)   Notwithstanding the other provisions of this subchapter, whenever
the Health Officer finds unsanitary or other conditions in the operation of a
food service establishment or retail food store which, in the Health Officer’s
judgement, constitute a substantial hazard to the public health, he or she may,
without warning, notice or hearing, issue a written notice to the license
holder or operator citing such condition, specifying the corrective action to
be taken, and specifying the time period within which such action shall be
taken and if deemed necessary, such order shall state that the license is
immediately suspended, and all operations as a food service establishment or
retail food store are to be immediately discontinued. Any person to whom such
an order is issued shall comply immediately herewith, but upon written petition
to the Health Authority shall be afforded a hearing within 72 hours.
(Prior Code, § 115.131)
§ 115.132 REINSTATEMENT OF SUSPENDED LICENSE.
   Any person whose license has been suspended may, at any time, make
application for a reinspection for the purpose of reinstatement of the license.
Within 48 hours following receipt of a written request, including a statement
signed by the applicant that in the applicant’s opinion the conditions causing
suspension of the license have been corrected, the Health Officer shall make a
reinspection. If the applicant is complying with the requirements of this
subchapter, their license shall be reinstated.
(Prior Code, § 115.132)
§ 115.133 REVOCATION OF LICENSE.
   (A)   For serious or repeated violations of any of the requirements of this
subchapter, or for interference with the Health Authority in the performance of
its duties, the license may be permanently revoked by the Mayor and City
Council after an opportunity for a hearing has been provided by the Health
Authority.
   (B)   Prior to such action, the Health Authority shall notify the license
holder, in writing, stating the reasons for which the license is subject to
revocation and advising that the license shall be permanently revoked at the
end of five days following service of such notice, unless a request for a
hearing is filed with the Health Authority, by the license holder, within such
five-day period.
   (C)   If no request for a hearing is filed within the five-day period, the
revocation of the license becomes final.
(Prior Code, § 115.133)
§ 115.134 HEARING.
   (A)   The hearings (suspension or revocation) provided for in this section
shall be conducted by the Health Authority at a time and place designated by
the Health Authority.
   (B)   Based upon the record of such hearing, the Health Authority shall make
a finding and shall sustain, modify or rescind any official notice or order
considered in the hearing.
(Prior Code, § 115.134)
§ 115.135 APPLICATION FOR NEW LICENSE AFTER REVOCATION.
   Whenever a revocation of a license has become final, the holder of the
revoked license may make written application for new license.
(Prior Code, § 115.135)
§ 115.136 FEES.
   The following fee for license may be required for food service
establishments and retail food stores. There shall be an annual charge of $50
at the time of the license renewal inspection for each permanent license and a
charge of $5 for each temporary license issued to cover the cost of issuing
said permits. This fee shall be collected by the City Clerk. There will be no
charge made for such license to any schools, religious, voluntary or non-profit
making community organizations and institutions.
(Prior Code, § 115.136)
§ 115.137 INSPECTION OF FOOD SERVICE ESTABLISHMENTS AND RETAIL FOOD STORES.
   At least once every 12 months, the Health Authority shall inspect each food
service establishment and retail food store located in the city and shall make
as many additional inspections and reinspections as are necessary for the
enforcement of this subchapter.
(Prior Code, § 115.137)
§ 115.138 ACCESS TO ESTABLISHMENT.
   The Health Authority, after proper identification, shall be permitted to
enter at any reasonable time any food service establishment or retail food
store within the city, for the purpose of making inspections to determine
compliance with this subchapter. The Health Authority shall be permitted to
examine the records of the establishment to obtain pertinent information
pertaining to food and supplies purchased, received or used, and persons
employed.
(Prior Code, § 115.138)
§ 115.139 REPORT OF INSPECTION.
   Whenever an inspection of a food service establishment or retail food store
is made, the finding shall be recorded on the inspection report forms set out
in §
115.129 of this chapter.
(Prior Code, § 115.139)
§ 115.140 CORRECTION OF VIOLATIONS.
   The completed inspection report form shall specify a reasonable period of
time for the correction of the violations found; and correction of the
violations shall be accomplished within the period specified, in accordance
with the following provisions.
   (A)   If an imminent health hazard exists, such as complete lack of
refrigeration or sewage backup into the establishment, the establishment shall
immediately cease food service operation. Operations shall not be resumed until
authorized by the Health Officer.
   (B)   All violations of four- or five-point weighted items, as indicated in
the “Rules and Regulations Governing Food Service Sanitation” shall be
corrected as soon as possible, but in any event, within ten days following
inspection. Within 15 days after inspection, the holder of the license shall
submit a written report to the regulatory authority stating that the four- or
five-point weighted violations have been corrected. A follow-up inspection
shall be conducted to confirm correction.
   (C)   All one- or two-point weighted items shall be corrected as soon as
possible, but in any event, by the time of the next routine inspection.
   (D)   When the rating score of the establishment is less than 60, the
establishment shall initiate corrective action on all identified violations
within 48 hours. One or more reinspections will be conducted at reasonable time
intervals to assure correction.
   (E)   In the case of temporary food service establishments, all violations
shall be corrected within 24 hours. If violations are not corrected within 24
hours, the establishment shall immediately cease food service operations until
authorized to resume by the regulatory authority.
   (F)   The inspection report shall state that failure to comply with any time
limits for corrections may result in cessation of food service operations. An
opportunity for hearing on the inspection findings or the time limitations or
both will be provided if a written request is filed with the regulatory
authority within ten days following cessation of operations. If a request for
hearing is received, a hearing shall be held within 20 days of receipt of the
request.
   (G)   Whenever a food service establishment is required under these
provisions to cease operations, it shall not resume operations until it is
