shown on reinspection that conditions responsible for the order to cease
operations no longer exist. Opportunity for reinspection shall be offered
within a reasonable time.
(Prior Code, § 115.140)
§ 115.141 INSPECTION OF RECORDS.
   Whenever the Health Officer makes an inspection, he or she shall record his
or her findings on an inspection report form provided for this purpose, and
shall furnish a copy of such inspection report form to the license holder or
operator. The current inspection report shall be posted in a conspicuous place
in the establishment.
(Prior Code, § 115.141)
§ 115.142 ISSUANCE OF NOTICES.
   (A)   Whenever the Health Officer makes an inspection of an establishment
and discovers that any of the requirements of this subchapter have been
violated, the Health Officer shall notify the license holder or operator of
such violations by means of an inspection report form or other written notice.
   (B)   In such notification, the Health Officer shall:
      (1)   Set forth the specific violations found;
      (2)   Establish a specific and reasonable period of time for the
correction of the violations found;
      (3)   State that failure to comply with any notice issued in accordance
with the provisions of this subchapter may result in immediate suspension of
the license or other prosecution; and
      (4)   State that an opportunity for appeal from any notice or inspection
findings will be provided if a written request for a hearing is filed with the
Health Authority within the period of time established in the notice of
correction.
(Prior Code, § 115.142)
§ 115.143 SERVICE OF NOTICES.
   Notices provided for under this section shall be deemed to have been
properly served when a copy of the original of the inspection report form or
other notice has been delivered personally to the license holder or person in
charge, or such notice has been sent by registered or certified mail, return
receipt requested, to the last known address of the license holder. The
original of such notice shall be filed with the records of the Health
Authority.
(Prior Code, § 115.143)
§ 115.144 EXAMINATION AND CONDEMNATION OF FOOD.
   Food may be examined or sampled by the Health Officer as often as may be
necessary to determine freedom from adulteration or misbranding. The Health
Officer may, upon written notice to the owner or person in charge, place a hold
order on any food which the Health Officer determines, or has probable cause to
believe to be unwholesome, or otherwise adulterated or misbranded. Under a hold
order, food shall be permitted to be suitably stored. It shall be unlawful for
any person to remove or alter a hold order notice or tag placed on food by the
Health Officer and neither such food, nor the containers thereof, shall be
relabeled, repacked, reprocessed, altered, disposed of or destroyed without
permission of the Health Officer, except on order by a court of competent
jurisdiction. After the owner or person in charge has had a hearing, as
provided for in the “Rules and Regulations Governing Food Service Sanitation”,
as amended, and on the basis of evidence produced at such hearing, or on the
basis of the Health Officer’s examination in the event a written request for a
hearing is not received, within ten days, the Health Officer may vacate the old
order or may by written order direct the owner or person in charge of the food
which was placed under the hold order to denature or destroy such food, or
bring it into compliance with the provisions of this subchapter.
(Prior Code, § 115.144) Penalty, see §
115.999
§ 115.145 ESTABLISHMENTS OUTSIDE JURISDICTION OF HEALTH AUTHORITY.
   Food from food service establishments outside the jurisdiction of the Health
Authority of the city, may be sold within the city, if such food service
establishments conform to the provisions of this subchapter, or to
substantially equivalent provisions. To determine the extent of compliance with
such provisions, the Health Officer may accept reports from responsible
authorities in other jurisdictions where such food service establishments are
located.
(Prior Code, § 115.145)
§ 115.146 PLAN REVIEW OF FUTURE CONSTRUCTION.
   When a food service establishment or retail food store is, hereafter,
constructed or extensively remodeled, or when an existing structure is
converted for use as food service establishment or retail food store, properly
prepared plans and specifications for such construction, remodeling or
alteration, showing layout, arrangement and construction materials of work
areas, and the location, size and type of fixed equipment and facilities, shall
be submitted to the Health Officer for approval before such work is begun.
(Prior Code, § 115.146)
§ 115.147 PROCEDURE WHEN INFECTION SUSPECTED.
   When the Health Officer has reasonable cause to suspect possibility of
disease transmission from any food service establishment or retail food store
employee, the Health Officer shall secure a morbidity history of the suspected
employee, or make such other investigation as may be indicated, and take
following measures:
   (A)   The immediate exclusion of the employee from all food service
establishments and retail food stores;
   (B)   The immediate closing of the establishment concerned until, in the
opinion of the Health Officer, no further danger of disease outbreak exists;
   (C)   Restriction of the employee’s services to some area of the
establishment where there would be no danger of transmitting disease; and
   (D)   Adequate medical and laboratory examination of the employee, and of
his or her body discharges.
(Prior Code, § 115.147) (Ord. 2515, passed 6-24-1980)
WASTE STORAGE AND DISPOSAL IN
FOOD SERVICE ESTABLISHMENTS
§ 115.160 DEFINITIONS.
   For the purpose of this subchapter, the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
   BUILDING COMMISSIONER, BUILDING INSPECTOR and HEALTH INSPECTOR. Those
persons who have been designated by the Mayor and City Council to administer
the affairs of the City Building and Health Department.
   DISPOSE or DISPOSAL. The removal of garbage, waste or refuse from the
container in which it is being stored to a location outside the city.
   FOOD. Any raw, cooked or processed edible substance, beverage or ingredient
used or intended for use or for sale in whole or in part for human consumption.
   FOOD PROCESSING ESTABLISHMENT. A commercial establishment in which food is
processed or otherwise prepared and packaged for human consumption.
   FOOD SERVICE ESTABLISHMENT. Any fixed or mobile restaurant; coffee shop;
cafeteria; short-order café; luncheonette; grill; tearoom/ sandwich shop; soda
fountain; tavern; bar; cocktail lounge; night club; roadside stand; industrial-
feeding establishment; private, public or non-profit organization or
institution routinely serving food; catering kitchen; commissary or similar
place in which food or drink is prepared for sale or for service on the
premises or elsewhere; and any other eating or drinking establishment or
operation where food is served or provided for the public with or without
charge.
   GARBAGE. Waste resulting from the handling, processing, preparation, cooking
and consumption of food and wastes from the handling, processing, storage and
sale of produce, whether in solid, liquid or semi-solid.
   MOBILE FOOD SERVICE ESTABLISH- MENT. Any food service establishment capable
of being moved from location to location or without a fixed location.
   REFUSE. Waste.
   RETAIL FOOD STORE. Retail grocery, meat market, poultry market, fish market,
fresh fruit and vegetable market, confectionary, nut store, retail bakery or
any other establishment, whether fixed or movable, where food, intended for
human consumption, off the premises, is prepared, handled, transported, sold or
offered for sale at retail.
   STORE or STORAGE. The containment of garbage, waste or refuse in a container
approved for such purpose.
   WASTE. Any garbage or other discarded materials.
(Prior Code, § 115.160) (Ord. 03-470, passed 12-9-2003)
§ 115.161 CONTAINERS.
   (A)   Those establishments defined in §
115.160 of this chapter are required to store garbage, waste and refuse in
water-tight, metal containers which are rust-resistant, non-absorbent, have
handles and have covers or lids which are capable of being secured to the
container or which can be closed in such a manner that the garbage, waste and
refuse stored inside the container cannot be visible from the exterior. All
containers for storage of garbage, waste or refuse in those establishments
defined in §
115.160 of this chapter must be approved by a representative of the City
Building and Health Department.
   (B)   Approval shall not be unreasonably withheld if the container conforms
to the requirements of this subchapter.
(Prior Code, § 115.161) (Ord. 03-470, passed 12-9-2003)
§ 115.162 DISPOSAL OF REFUSE.
   Those establishments defined in §
115.160 of this chapter are required to dispose of garbage, waste and refuse at
such intervals of time as are necessary to prevent the garbage, waste and
refuse stored inside the containers torn being exposed to the outside in such a
manner that it protrudes over the top of the container or prevents the
container cover or lid from being securely fastened or closed.
(Prior Code, § 115.162) (Ord. 03-470, passed 12-9-2003) Penalty, see §
115.999
§ 115.163 STORAGE IN CONTAINERS.
   Those establishments defined in §
115.160 of this chapter shall not allow waste, refuse or garbage to be stored
on top of or outside of the container or containers which are used for storage
of waste, refuse or garbage prior to its disposal. These establishments shall
also be required to keep the top or cover of the container closed at all times.
(Prior Code, § 115.163) (Ord. 03-470, passed 12-9-2003) Penalty, see §
115.999
§ 115.164 VIOLATIONS.
   (A)   It shall be unlawful and a violation of this subchapter for any
establishment as defined in §
115.160 of this chapter to fail to provide for storage of waste, refuse and
garbage in containers as described in §
115.161 of this chapter.
   (B)   It shall be unlawful and a violation of this subchapter for any
establishment as defined in §
115.160 of this chapter to fail to provide for disposal of waste, refuse and
garbage at such intervals as are required and necessary to prevent accumulation
in the manner described in §
115.162 of this chapter.
   (C)   It shall be unlawful and a violation of this subchapter for any
establishment as defined in §
115.160 of this chapter to allow waste, refuse or garbage to be stored on top
of or outside of a container or containers which are used for storage of waste,
refuse or garbage prior to its disposal.
   (D)   It shall also be unlawful and a violation of this subchapter for any
establishment as defined in §
115.160 of this chapter to fail to keep a top or cover of the storage container
closed at all times.
(Prior Code, § 115.164) (Ord. 03-470, passed 12-9-2003) Penalty, see §
115.999
§ 115.165 INSPECTION OF STORAGE AND DISPOSAL; HEARINGS.
   The Building Commissioner, Building Department Inspectors and the Health
Inspector for the city are authorized to inspect the storage and disposal of
waste, refuse and garbage by those establishments defined in §
115.160 of this chapter and to issue notices of violations and a summons to the
licensee of the establishment addressed to the address of the establishment
commanding the licensee to appear at a hearing conducted pursuant to the
provisions of §
32.04 of this code of ordinances. The Building Commissioner, Building Inspector
or Health Inspector issuing the notice of violation and summons shall
photograph the violation as proof thereof and preserve said photograph for the
hearing.
(Prior Code, § 115.165) (Ord. 03-470, passed 12-9-2003)
§ 115.166 EFFECTIVE DATE.
   This subchapter shall be in full force and effect from and after its
passage, approval and publication in pamphlet form as required by applicable
law.
(Prior Code, § 115.166) (Ord. 03-470, passed 12-9-2003)
FOOD VENDORS’ EXTERMINATION
REQUIREMENTS
§ 115.180 DEFINITION.
   For the purpose of this subchapter, the following definition shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
   FOOD VENDOR. Any person, partnership, corporation, limited liability company
or other business entity engaged in any business which keeps for sale, sells or
serves food to the general public for human consumption, whether at retail or
wholesale and whether for consumption on the premises of the business or
elsewhere.
(Prior Code, § 115.180) (Ord. 00-332, passed 9-26-2000)
§ 115.181 REQUIRED EXTERMINATION.
   Every food vendor doing business within the geographic limits of the city
shall be required to have the premises where he, she or they do business as
food vendors exterminated for pests, insects, rats, mice, rodents and other
vermin at least one time each month, beginning in the first month after passage
of this subchapter and continuing each month thereafter.
(Prior Code, § 115.181) (Ord. 00-332, passed 9-26-2000) Penalty, see §
115.999
§ 115.182 CERTIFICATES REQUIRED.
   Every food vendor doing business within the geographic limits of the city
shall submit on a quarterly basis, beginning at the end of the third month
following passage of this subchapter and continuing quarterly thereafter,
certificates from a duly licensed exterminator or exterminator whose
qualifications have been approved by the Health Inspector for the city, showing
that the monthly exterminations have been performed for those months included
in the quarterly period.
(Prior Code, § 115.182) (Ord. 00-332, passed 9-26-2000) Penalty, see §
115.999
§ 115.183 NOTICE TO CLOSE; APPEAL.
   (A)   Should a food vendor fail to provide the certification required by §
115.182 of this chapter to the Health Inspector within five days of the end of
any quarter, the Health Inspector shall issue a written notice to the food
vendor that the premises where the food vendor is doing business shall be
ordered closed and the business license suspended unless evidence of
extermination, as required by this subchapter, is presented to the Health
Inspector within five business days or until a proper extermination is
conducted by a duly licensed or approved exterminator and certification of such
extermination presented to the Health Inspector.
   (B)   Any food vendor may appeal the order of the Health Inspector to close
the business to the office of the Building Commissioner who may affirm, reverse
or modify the decision of the Health Inspector based upon the information
presented.
(Prior Code, § 115.183) (Ord. 00-332, passed 9-26-2000)
§ 115.184 EFFECTIVE DATE.
   This subchapter shall be in full force and effect from and after its
passage, approval and publication in pamphlet form as provided by law. A full,
true and complete copy of this subchapter shall be published in pamphlet form,
by authority of the City Council as corporate authorities.
(Prior Code, § 115.184) (Ord. 00-332, passed 9-26-2000)
ICE DEALERS
§ 115.195 LICENSE REQUIRED.
   No person shall engage in the business of selling ice at retail in the city
without securing a license.
(Prior Code, § 115.195) Penalty, see §
115.999
§ 115.196 APPLICATION FOR LICENSE.
   Any person desiring to engage in the business of selling ice at retail shall
make application to the City Clerk. The application shall contain the name and
residence of the applicant and other information desired by the City Clerk.
Upon payment of the license fee, the City Clerk shall issue a license, attested
by the proper city authorities, to sell ice at retail.
(Prior Code, § 115.196)
§ 115.197 LICENSE FEE.
   (A)   The license fee to be paid by the applicant shall be $50 per year.
   (B)   All licenses shall expire on the April 30 next after the date of
issuance.
   (C)   If a license is granted for less than one year, the license fee shall
be reduced pro rata.
(Prior Code, § 115.197) (Ord. 2315, passed 3-23-1976)
MOBILE FOOD VENDORS AND MOBILE FOOD VEHICLES
§ 115.210 DEFINITIONS.
   For the purpose of this subchapter, the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
   CITY EVENT. A temporary special event sponsored by a governmental entity,
church or nonprofit organization. A CITY EVENT also includes private events in
residential districts and private corporate-sponsored events in commercial,
industrial or U-TOD districts where no items are offered for sale to the
general public not associated with and/or participating in the event. CITY
EVENTS may last one to three days and must be approved by the city.
   MOBILE FOOD VEHICLE. A self-contained food service operation located in a
readily moveable, motorized, wheeled or towed vehicle, with facilities for
storing, preparing, displaying and/or serving food or non-alcoholic beverages
for retail sale intended for individual consumption, commonly referred to as a
food truck. A MOBILE FOOD VEHICLE is a motorized vehicle registered as a
commercial vehicle that is not used for any purposes other than as a mobile
food vendor, mobile food dispenser or mobile food preparer business.
   MOBILE FOOD VENDOR. Any person engaged in the business of preparing and/or
serving food or non-alcoholic beverages from a mobile food vehicle or pushcart
while traveling from place to place upon the public ways.
   PUSHCARTS. Small handcarts or barrows from which fruit, ice cream or other
goods are sold in the street.
   SPONSORING BUSINESS. The individual, corporation, firm, partnership,
association, proprietorship or other legal entity that owns and/or operates the
business at the location where a mobile food vendor will operate its mobile
food vehicle under this subchapter.
(Ord. 2022-030, passed 4-26-2022)
§ 115.211 MOBILE FOOD VENDOR REGISTRATION.
   (A)   Registration required. No person shall operate a mobile food vehicle
within the city’s boundaries without first registering as a mobile food vendor.
For any business having a valid business registration for a permanent physical
business location in the city as required by Title XI of this code, the
requirement to register as a mobile food vendor shall not apply provided the
information required for a mobile vehicle vendor registration, as set forth
below, is provided with the business registration application.
   (B)   Required information. The Building Official or designee shall provide
a form for application for a mobile food vendor as required under this
subchapter. The application shall require the following:
      (1)   The name, address and phone number of the applicant;
      (2)   A government-issued photo ID from all applicants, owners and
business entities controlling persons and registered agents;
      (3)   The federal Employer Identification Number (EIN) and State of
Illinois File Number (if a business entity) and Illinois Department of Revenue
Account ID for the business;
      (4)   The relationship of the applicant to the mobile food vehicle;
      (5)   The name, address and phone number of an owner or other responsible
person to be contacted in case of an emergency;
      (6)   The name of the mobile food vehicle;
      (7)   A photo and/or detailed description of the mobile food vehicle;
      (8)   The vehicle identification number;
      (9)   Proof of vehicle insurance and registration;
      (10)   A general description of the types of items to be sold from the
mobile food vehicle;
      (11)   A valid copy of the operating permit issued by the Cook County
Health Department for the mobile food vehicle;
      (12)   A copy of the current State of Illinois sales tax registration;
      (13)   A valid retail food establishment or shared kitchen user business
license, if the mobile food dispenser license applicant is going to produce
food for sale;
      (14)   A certificate of general liability insurance in the amount of
$1,000,000 and listing the city as additionally insured. No cancellation or
reduction in coverage may occur during the effective period of the mobile food
vendor registration; and
      (15)   Additional information may be required as determined by the city
from time to time.
   (C)   Fee term.
      (1)   The required fee for each registration issued under this subchapter
shall be $100. The fee shall be collected upon application. The effective term
of the registration shall commence on January 1 and expire at midnight on
December 31 of each year. The renewal of each existing registration under this
subchapter shall be $50.
      (2)   If the mobile food vendor is only operating temporarily in the city
for a city event, the fee for registration may be waived. However, an
application must still be submitted to the Building and Zoning Department.
(Ord. 2022-030, passed 4-26-2022) Penalty, see §
115.999
§ 115.212 MOBILE FOOD VEHICLE AND PUSHCART PERMITS.
   (A)   Permit required.
      (1)   In addition to the mobile food vendor registration required under
this subchapter, no person shall operate a mobile food vehicle within the city
without a permit. In regard to mobile food vehicles, the sponsoring business
for the location at which the mobile food vendor intends to operate its mobile
food vehicle must first obtain a permit from the Building Official or designee.
      (2)   In addition to the pushcart vendor registration required under this
subchapter, no person shall operate a pushcart within the city without a
permit.
   (B)   Required information, mobile food vehicles. The Building Official,
City Clerk, or designee shall provide a form for application for a mobile food
vehicle permit as required under this subchapter. The permit application shall
require the following:
      (1)   The name, address and phone number of the owner of the sponsoring
business;
      (2)   The name, address and phone number of the mobile food vendor;
      (3)   Written permission signed by the property owner for where the
mobile food vehicle will be located specifying the date and hours of operation
of the mobile food vehicle, with any restrictions imposed by the property owner
clearly identified; and
      (4)   A site plan clearly depicting the following:
         (a)   Property boundaries of the parcel on which the mobile food
vehicle will be operating;
         (b)   Footprint and dimensions of all existing and proposed buildings
and structures on the property;
         (c)   All curb cuts, drive aisles and parking spaces on the property;
         (d)   The proposed location of the mobile food vehicle, including the
number of parking spaces that would be occupied by the mobile food vehicle and
related activities; and
         (e)   A description of all proposed lighting, signage, trash
receptacles, other equipment and other activities associated with the mobile
food vehicle.
   (C)   Required information, pushcart vendors. The Building Official, City
Clerk or designee shall provide a form for application for a pushcart permit as
required under this subchapter.
   (D)   Fee; duration. The required fee for each mobile food vehicle permit
issued under this subchapter shall be $25. The permit shall be valid only for
the date and times listed on the permit. The required fee for a pushcart permit
is $100. The fee shall be collected upon application. The effective term of the
permit shall commence on January 1 and expire at midnight on December 31 of
each year. The renewal of each existing permit under this subchapter shall be
$50.
   (E)   Multiple dates under a single permit, mobile food vehicles. A
sponsoring business may submit one permit for the same mobile food vehicle to
operate at the same location for more than one date. The permit application
shall list every date and the hours of operation of the mobile food vehicle on
each date. The requirements of §
115.211 of this chapter and this §
115.212 must be complied with for each individual date the mobile food vehicle
operates at the location.
   (F)   Approval standards. No mobile food vehicle permit or pushcart permit
shall be issued unless the applicant demonstrates compliance with all of the
following.
      (1)   The mobile food vehicle or pushcart shall not be located on a
property that is less than 250 feet from a property containing a restaurant
unless written consent by the proprietor of such restaurant is provided with
the mobile food vehicle permit application.
      (2)   The mobile food vehicle shall not be parked within 100 feet of a
residential district or a property recommended for residential use in the
city’s Comprehensive Plan unless the mobile food vehicle is operating on
private property in such residential district for a private event and is not
offering items for sale to the general public not associated with and/or
participating in the event.
      (3)   The mobile food vehicle shall be parked on an improved surface.
      (4)   The mobile food vehicle shall not be located within any required
setback of the underlying zoning district.
      (5)   The mobile food vehicle or pushcart shall not be located within a
handicap accessible parking space or any parking space required for the
permanent/primary use(s) on the property.
      (6)   The mobile food vehicle or pushcart shall not be located or
operated in such a manner that it interferes with vehicle or pedestrian
visibility, traffic flow, emergency vehicle access or pedestrian circulation.
      (7)   The mobile food vehicle or pushcart shall be located a minimum of
15 feet from all fire hydrants and Fire Department connections.
      (8)   A permanent divide must exist between the front driving area and
the back cook/prep area of the mobile food vehicle, and a grease trap must be
installed under a three-compartment sink.
      (9)   The mobile food vehicle or pushcart must pass an initial health
inspection by the City Health Inspector, meeting all Health Code requirements.
The mobile food vehicle or pushcart must maintain sanitary conditions,
including frequent hand washing and proper food temperature controls, and pass
every subsequent health inspection.
      (10)   The mobile food vehicle or pushcart must pass an initial fire
inspection by the City Fire Inspector, meeting all Fire Code and Fire
Department requirements. The mobile food vehicle or pushcart must maintain fire
safety protocols, including installation of an appropriate fire suppression
system and carrying a combustible gas detector, and pass every subsequent fire
inspection.
   (G)   Permit displayed. A copy of the approved mobile food vehicle or
pushcart permit shall be clearly displayed on the mobile food vehicle or
pushcart at all times while operating in the city.
   (H)   Exceptions. Notwithstanding the provisions of this section, any mobile
food vehicle operating at a city event shall be exempt from the requirement to
obtain a mobile food vehicle permit provided the sponsoring entity or
organization provides the city with a list of valid Cook County Health
Department permits, State of Illinois sales tax registrations and certificates
of insurance, with copies thereof, for all mobile food vehicles participating
in the event.
(Ord. 2022-030, passed 4-26-2022) Penalty, see §
115.999
§ 115.213 MOBILE FOOD VEHICLE OPERATIONAL RESTRICTIONS.
   (A)   No fixed location. Mobile food vehicles that have not obtained a
permit as provided in this subchapter must move from place to place upon the
public ways and shall not be operated at a fixed location except as otherwise
provided herein. Mobile food vehicle stops shall be made only to service
customers and shall not exceed in any one block whichever is less:
      (1)   A total of two hours; or
      (2)   The maximum permitted period for parking.
   (B)   Sound amplification. No mobile food vehicle or pushcart shall be
equipped with any electronic sound-amplifying device. Mobile food vehicles or
pushcarts employing musical or noise-making devices shall only sound said
devices while traversing the public way, not while standing or parked.
   (C)   Hours of operation. Mobile food vehicles shall not service customers
between the hours of 12:00 a.m. and 6:00 a.m. Pushcarts shall not service
customers between the hours of 9:00 p.m. to 6:00 a.m.
   (D)   Location. Mobile food vehicles shall not park or stand:
      (1)   Within 20 feet of a crosswalk;
      (2)   Within 30 feet of a stop light or stop sign;
      (3)   Adjacent to a protected bike lane; or
      (4)   Within 200 feet of any principal customer entrance to a restaurant.
   (E)   Sales. No sale shall be made from a mobile food vehicle except from
the curb side thereof, and then only when such vehicle is standing or parked in
a legal parking spot.
   (F)   Food preparation. No food that is sold or served from a mobile food
vehicle or a pushcart may be stored or prepared in a residential home.
(Ord. 2022-030, passed 4-26-2022) Penalty, see §
115.999
§ 115.999 PENALTY.
   (A)   Any person violating any provision of this chapter for which no
specific penalty is required shall be subject to §
10.99 of this code of ordinances.
   (B)   (1)   Any establishment defined in §
115.160 of this chapter found to be in violation of §§
115.160 through
115.166 of this chapter after a hearing conducted pursuant to §
32.04 of this code of ordinances shall, upon such a finding, be subject to a
fine of not less than $50, nor more than $750, at the discretion of the Hearing
Officer. Each day that a violation continues after the day notice of the
violation and summons have been served in accordance with the terms and
provisions hereof shall be deemed a separate offense.
      (2)   In the event the licensee of an establishment defined in §
115.160 of this chapter fails to pay any fine imposed, after a hearing and
conviction for a violation of §§
115.160 through
115.166 of this chapter, within 30 days of the date of the imposition of the
fine, the business registration and license for the establishment shall be
immediately suspended until payment is made.
      (3)   (a)   In the event the licensee of an establishment defined in §
115.160 of this chapter is convicted of three or more violations of §§
115.160 through
115.166 of this chapter for violations occurring within any 90-day period, the
licensee of the establishment shall be required to appear before the Community
Development Committee of the City Council for a hearing to show cause why the
business registration and license should not be suspended or revoked. After
such hearing, the Community Development Committee may act to suspend or revoke
the license.
         (b)   If the Community Development Committee finds sufficient cause to
suspend or revoke the establishment’s business registration and license, the
establishment shall cease operations for the period specified by the Community
Development Committee. If the establishment desires to appeal the decision of
the Community Development Committee, it shall apply to the Mayor, in writing,
for a hearing before the Mayor and City Council. The Mayor and City Council may
affirm, reverse or modify the decision of the Community Development Committee.
(Prior Code, § 115.999) (Ord. 03-470, passed 12-9-2003)

JUNK DEALERS
§ 116.01 DEFINITION.
   For the purpose of this subchapter, the following definition shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
   JUNK DEALER. Any person, firm, corporation, partnership or other entity who
collects, procures, obtains and/or sells items which have been discarded,
thrown away or set out for collection by the city’s Sanitation Department or
any other garbage collection service.
(Prior Code, § 116.01) (Ord. 88-143, passed 10-11-1988)
§ 116.02 LICENSE REQUIRED.
   Every junk dealer shall obtain a license from the City Clerk and pay as a
fee for said license the sum of $25.
(Prior Code, § 116.02) (Ord. 88-143, passed 10-11-1988)
§ 116.03 RESTRICTIONS.
   (A)   It shall be unlawful for any junk dealer to collect, obtain, possess
or pick up any recyclable item placed for collection at a residence as part of
the city’s recycling program.
   (B)   All junk dealer licenses issued with the city shall contain a
statement in regard to the aforementioned restriction, as well as a statement
advising the licensee of the boundaries of the area within the city in which
the city’s recycling program is being conducted.
(Prior Code, § 116.03) (Ord. 88-143, passed 10-11-1988) Penalty, see §
116.99
SECONDHAND DEALERS
§ 116.15 ISSUANCE OF LICENSE.
   The City Council may grant licenses to persons who produce satisfactory
evidence of good character to carry on the business or conduct a secondhand
store in the city.
(Prior Code, § 116.15)
§ 116.16 LICENSE FEE.
   Licenses to secondhand dealers shall be issued for semiannual periods,
beginning on May 1 and November 1 in each year. The fee shall be $30 for each
period or fraction thereof, payable in advance.
(Prior Code, § 116.16) (Ord. 1669, passed 4-14-1952)
§ 116.17 BOND.
   Every person licensed shall, at the time of receiving the license, execute a
bond to the city. The bond shall have good and sufficient sureties approved by
the City Collector or City Clerk in the sum of $500 and conditioned for the due
observance of all ordinances of the city now in force or which may hereafter be
passed respecting dealers in secondhand articles.
(Prior Code, § 116.17)
§ 116.18 DEALING WITHOUT LICENSE PROHIBITED.
   (A)   No person shall carry on or conduct a secondhand store without being
especially licensed for such purpose. Any license issued under the provisions
of this subchapter shall designate the place in which the person so licensed
shall carry on such business. However, the business shall not be conducted in
any place other than that designated by the license.
   (B)   No person licensed under the provisions of this subchapter shall be
permitted to solicit business for a secondhand store upon any street or public
highway of the city.
(Prior Code, § 116.18) Penalty, see §
116.99
§ 116.19 RECORD OF PURCHASES.
   Every person licensed shall keep a book in which shall be fairly written, at
the time of the purchase of any article or thing pertaining to such person’s
business, an accurate account and description of the article or thing
purchased, the price paid, the precise time of making the purchase and the name
and residence of the person from whom the purchase was made.
(Prior Code, § 116.19) Penalty, see §
116.99
§ 116.20 INSPECTION OF RECORDS.
   The book shall, at all reasonable times, be open to the inspection of the
Mayor, Aldermen and any member of the police force.
(Prior Code, § 116.20) Penalty, see §
116.99
§ 116.21 LICENSEE NOT PERMITTED TO HOLD PAWNBROKER LICENSE.
   No person licensed under the provisions of this subchapter shall, during the
period of his or her license, receive or hold a license to carry on the
business of a pawnbroker.
(Prior Code, § 116.21) Penalty, see §
116.99
§ 116.22 LICENSE TO STATE WHERE BUSINESS TO BE CARRIED ON.
   Every license granted to any dealer in secondhand articles shall designate
the house or place in which the person receiving the license shall be
authorized to carry on the business.
(Prior Code, § 116.22)
§ 116.23 CHANGE OF LOCATION.
   (A)   In case any person licensed shall remove the place of business from
the place designated in the license, such person shall immediately give notice
to the City Collector and have the change noted upon the license.
   (B)   The number of the place of business shall be changed on the sides of
the vehicles used by the licensed dealer to correspond with the new place of
business.
(Prior Code, § 116.23)
§ 116.24 PURCHASE FROM MINORS PROHIBITED.
   No keeper of a secondhand store shall purchase any articles whatsoever from
any minors without the written consent of the minor’s parents or guardians.
(Prior Code, § 116.24) Penalty, see §
116.99
§ 116.25 HOURS OF BUSINESS.
   No dealer in secondhand articles shall purchase any goods, articles or
things from any person between the hours of 10:00 p.m. and 6:00 a.m.
(Prior Code, § 116.25) Penalty, see §
116.99
§ 116.26 ARTICLES TO BE HELD TEN DAYS BEFORE SALE.
   No dealer in secondhand articles shall expose for sale, sell or dispose of
any article or articles within ten days of the time of purchasing the articles,
nor until the articles have been in the premises at least ten days.
(Prior Code, § 116.26) Penalty, see §
116.99
§ 116.27 DEALER TO REPORT LOST OR STOLEN GOODS.
   Every dealer in secondhand articles who has received or is in possession of
any goods, articles or things which have been lost or stolen, or alleged or
supposed to have been lost or stolen, shall on demand exhibit the same to any
member of the Police Department or to any member of City Council.
(Prior Code, § 116.27) Penalty, see §
116.99
§ 116.28 INSPECTION AND SUPERVISION OF DEALERS.
   The Chief of Police or any officer designated by the Chief shall have
general supervision over all dealers in secondhand articles. The Chief shall
also have power to inspect their respective places of business and all articles
or things kept therein whenever the Chief shall deem it necessary so to do.
(Prior Code, § 116.28)
§ 116.29 PROHIBITED ACTS; REVOCATION OF LICENSE.
   (A)   (1)   No person conducting and maintaining a secondhand store shall
break up old boilers, iron or other junk by means of hammers, sledges or other
mechanical devices in a manner that will disturb the peace and quietude of the
residents in the immediate vicinity of the secondhand store.
      (2)   Such person shall not do any other act or acts which will disturb
the peace and quietude of any residents.
   (B)   No person shall conduct or maintain any such place of business in a
manner in which the premises and the sidewalks in front of the business are
kept and permitted to remain in an unsanitary condition.
   (C)   The Mayor of the city may revoke the license of any person violating
any of the provisions of this section or §
116.28 of this chapter, or for violating any other city ordinance relating to
the business of a secondhand dealer.
(Prior Code, § 116.29) Penalty, see §
116.99
SCRAP METAL
§ 116.40 PURPOSE.
   This chapter is enacted to protect, preserve and promote the health, safety,
welfare, peace and protection of private property of the citizens and
businesses of the city through the regulation of scrap metal dealers so as to
more effectively prohibit theft of scrap metal, and to regulate the sale of
scrap metal.
(Ord. 2025-019, passed 4-22-2025)
§ 116.41 DEFINITION.
   As used in this chapter, the following terms shall have the meaning
indicated in this section:
   SCRAP METAL. Any ferrous or nonferrous metal that is no longer used for its
original purpose and is capable of being processed for reuse by a metal
recycling facility, including, but not limited to: iron, brass, wire, cable,
copper, bronze, aluminum, platinum, lead, solder, steel, stainless steel,
catalytic converters, or other similar obsolete ferrous or nonferrous
materials, but shall not include recyclable aluminum cans.
   SCRAP METAL DEALER. Any entity (person, firm, company, partnership,
association, or corporation) that purchases products containing ferrous or
nonferrous metals for recycling or resale,
(Ord. 2025-019, passed 4-22-2025)
§ 116.42 SCRAP METAL DEALER’S LICENSE.
   Any person, firm, partnership, corporation or other entity conducting or
operating the business of a scrap metal dealer shall first obtain a scrap metal
dealer's license issued by the City of Blue Island.
(Ord. 2025-019, passed 4-22-2025)
§ 116.43 ELECTRONIC DATABASE REQUIREMENTS.
   (A)   By January 1, 2013, every scrap metal dealer shall install and
maintain a retrievable electronic database containing a consecutively numbered
record of each and every purchase.
   (B)   Any person selling, exchanging, or trading ferrous or nonferrous
materials shall present to the scrap metal dealer a valid driver's license and/
or a picture identification from a state or federal issuing agency.
   (C)   At the time of purchase, scrap metal dealers shall enter into the
electronic database all of the following information:
      (1)   Name, gender, date of birth, and residential address of seller;
      (2)   Date of the scrap metal purchase;
      (3)   Driver's license number and/or a picture identification number;
      (4)   Amount paid;
      (5)   Kind of metal purchased or received;
      (6)   Number of pounds of each kind; and
      (7)   License plate number of vehicle delivering material.
   (D)   Transaction record. The scrap metal dealer shall prepare a transaction
record containing all of the information required above. Buyer and seller must
sign the record.
   (E)   The electronic database, transaction records, and associated records
and photocopies shall be open to the inspection of the police or other officer,
during normal business hours without warrant or subpoena and shall be kept in
good faith and preserved on site by such dealer for a period of three years
from date of the scrap metal sale.
   (F)   The scrap metal dealer shall ask where the scrap metal was obtained
for the purpose of determining if purchasing scrap metal from the seller is a
lawful transaction. If the seller presents a bill of sale, receipt or other
document indicating lawful possession of the scrap metal, the dealer shall
photocopy such document and maintain it with the transaction information
otherwise required by this section.
   (G)   Declaration. The scrap metal dealer shall require a declaration signed
and dated by the person or persons from whom the scrap metal was purchased
which states the following:
   "I, the undersigned, affirm under penalty of law, to the best of my
knowledge and belief, that the property that is subject to this transaction is
not stolen property."
   (H)   No scrap metal dealer shall purchase or otherwise receive from a minor
under the age of 18 any scrap metal of any kind except aluminum cans.
   (I)   No transaction receipt or entry into the electronic database shall be
required for the sale and purchase of aluminum cans, regardless of the seller's
age.
(Ord. 2025-019, passed 4-22-2025)
§ 116.44 PURCHASE OF HVAC SCRAP METAL; REQUIREMENTS.
   (A)   It is an offense for a scrap metal dealer to knowingly accept any HVAC
components unless accompanied by written authorization for a licensed HVAC
business evidencing that the components were legally removed and the seller has
the legal right to sell the material.
   (B)   Payment for HVAC scrap metal shall be:
      (1)   No cash.
      (2)   Check or money order made payable to a licensed HVAC contractor
named by the seller.
      (3)   After a period of three business days from the date of the scrap
transaction such check or money order shall be mailed to the business address
of the HVAC contractor.
      (4)   Checks may not be converted by a scrap metal dealer or by any
related entity.
(Ord. 2025-019, passed 4-22-2025)
§ 116.45 RESTRICTED PURCHASE EXCEPTIONS.
   (A)   It is an offense to knowingly sell or attempt to sell, and to
knowingly purchase or attempt to purchase, the following types of scrap metal:
      (1)   Materials sold by a business but brought by an individual, such as
new materials that are part of a manufacturing process.
      (2)   Property which is often used by government, utilities, railroads or
other specific industries such as guardrails, manhole covers, traffic signs,
railroad signs, copper gutters or downspouts, certain cables used only in high
voltage transmission lines, historical markers and cemetery plaques.
      (3)   Full-sized new materials such as those used in construction, and
equipment or tools used by contractors.
      (4)   Property which might not be new but is clearly suspect, such as
traffic signs or ten-foot lengths of copper or aluminum spouts of gutters.
      (5)   Materials which are clearly marked as property belonging to a
business or someone else other than the seller.
      (6)   Catalytic converters unless purchased directly from a vehicle
repair business.
      (7)   Copper wire that was burned in whole or in part to remove the
insulation unless the seller can produce written proof to the scrap metal
dealer that the wire was lawfully burned.
   (B)   An exception to this section is if the person attempting to sell the
scrap metal provides reasonable, written documentation that the seller is the
owner of the scrap metal or is an employee, agent, or other person authorized
to sell the scrap metal on behalf of the owner. The dealer shall make a photo
copy of any documentation provided and maintain it with the transaction record.
(Ord. 2025-019, passed 4-22-2025)
§ 116.46 PURCHASE OF SCRAP METAL REQUIREMENTS.
   (A)   Payment for scrap metal shall be:
      (1)   No cash.
      (2)   By check or money order made payable to the seller who conducted
the transaction.
      (3)   By check made payable to the business or company for all industrial
accounts.
      (4)   After a period of three business days from the date the scrap
transaction such check or money order shall be mailed to the seller's address
listed on the government issued identification card used in the transaction.
   (B)   Hold notice. If the scrap dealer suspects the scrap metal is stolen or
lost the dealer shall immediately notify the police department and provide the
seller's personal information. If there is reasonable suspicion that the
property may be stolen, a ten-day hold over will be placed on the property.
(Ord. 2025-019, passed 4-22-2025)
§ 116.47 EXCEPTIONS.
   The provisions of this subchapter do not apply to the following:
   (A)   Electrical contractors or licensed skilled craftspeople.
   (B)   Agencies or instrumentalities of the state of Illinois or the United
States.
   (C)   Units of local government that have contracted with the recyclable
metal dealer in the disposal of metal street signs.
   (D)   Common carriers with a license to haul.
   (E)   Licensed businesses or employees of licensed businesses regularly
engaged in the business of manufacturing recyclable metal at retail or
wholesale, and razing, demolishing, destroying or removing buildings.
   (F)   Transactions between licensed recyclable metal dealers.
   (G)   Purchases from public utilities if a bill of sale or other written
evidence of title to the recyclable metal is provided.
(Ord. 2025-019, passed 4-22-2025)
§ 116.48 PENALTIES.
   (A)   Violation of this chapter shall be punishable by a fine not to exceed
more than $750 per violation. Every transaction conducted by a scrap metal
merchant in violation of the provisions of this chapter shall be deemed a
separate violation.
   (B)   In addition to the penalties described in this section, the city may
revoke any license or permit issued for the business of scrap metal merchant.
   (C)   Nothing in this section shall be construed to preclude any applicable
criminal prosecution or civil remedies.
(Ord. 2025-019, passed 4-22-2025)
§ 116.99 PENALTY.
   (A)   Any person violating any provision of this chapter for which no
specific penalty is prescribed shall be subject to §
10.99 of this code of ordinances.
   (B)   Any person, firm, corporation, partnership or other entity who
violates the provisions of §§
116.01 through
116.03 of this chapter shall be fined not less than $50, nor more than $750,
for each such violation.
(Prior Code, § 116.99)
