AUTOMATIC LAUNDRIES
§ 117.001 LICENSE REQUIRED.
   (A)   No person, firm or corporation shall own or operate any automatic
laundry store in the city without first having obtained a license so to do.
   (B)   For the purposes of this subchapter, an AUTOMATIC LAUNDRY STORE is
defined as any store, room or other enclosed place within any building where
more than three automatic laundry machines or automatic clothes dryers or
automatic combination laundry and clothes dryer machines, or any combination of
such machines in excess of three, all controlled and operated by means of
automatic coin metering devices, are located and open to use by the public.
(Prior Code, § 117.001) (Ord. 1862, passed 11-28-1960)
§ 117.002 APPLICATION FOR LICENSE.
   Any person desiring a license for an automatic laundry store shall make
application in writing therefor to the City Clerk. The application shall, among
other things, state the name and address of the person requesting such license,
the location of the store to be licensed, the number and the description of the
automatic laundry machines or automatic clothes dryers or automatic combination
laundry and clothes dryer machines or any combination of such machines to be
located in the store. In the case of an original application for a store not
theretofore legally in operation the application shall be accompanied by a set
of plans and specifications showing the manner in which such machines shall be
installed, showing all plumbing connections, electrical wire connections, and
provisions for ventilation, all of which shall be in compliance with the
Building Code, the Fire Code and other applicable ordinances of the city. In
the case of an initial application, the City Clerk shall submit the aforesaid
plans and specifications to the Building Commissioner of the city for the
Commissioner’s examination and approval before the issuance of any license
hereunder.
(Prior Code, § 117.002) (Ord. 1862, passed 11-28-1960)
§ 117.003 MAINTENANCE REGULATIONS.
   Every licensee to whom a license shall be issued shall cause the automatic
laundry store for which such license is issued to be maintained and operated so
as to satisfy the following requirements.
   (A)   The premises shall be kept in good repair and maintained in a clean
and sanitary condition as to floors, walls, woodwork, machinery and fixtures.
   (B)   All machinery and equipment shall be kept in good working condition
and shall be so installed and maintained so that the customers of said store
and the public generally, at no time have access to the utility serving the
equipment nor exposure to any unguarded moving parts of the machinery; except
that, the customers shall be permitted all necessary access to the operating
controls of the machines employed in the business.
   (C)   The store shall maintain under continuous operating conditions a
minimum temperature of 140°F for all hot water employed in the clothes washing
processes.
   (D)   The store shall be kept well lighted during all of the hours when the
store is open for business, If off-street parking is provided for automobiles
of customers of the store, the off-street parking area or areas shall be
surfaced with crushed stone or other suitable hard surface materials, shall be
level, shall be provided with adequate driveway or driveways for ingress or
egress and shall be well lighted during all the hours of darkness.
(Prior Code, § 117.003) (Ord. 1862, passed 11-28-1960) Penalty, see §
10.99
§ 117.004 LICENSE FEE; FOOD AND BEVERAGE MACHINES.
   (A)   The annual license fee for an automatic laundry store shall be $50,
plus $5 for each automatic laundry machine, automatic clothes dryer, automatic
combination laundry and clothes dryer machine, or any combination of such
machines in excess of ten.
   (B)   Every license shall expire on April 30 next after its issuance.
   (C)   The license fee shall not cover, nor shall it authorize, the use or
maintenance in any laundry store of automatic food or beverage dispensing
devices or machines.
   (D)   Any automatic food or beverage dispensing device or machine which may
be installed or located in the laundry store shall be done in compliance with
and subject to the requirements of any ordinance of the city now or hereafter
in effect licensing and regulating automatic food or beverage dispensing
machines or devices.
(Prior Code, § 117.004) (Ord. 2322, passed 3-23-1976)
DRY CLEANERS AND DYERS
§ 117.015 DEFINITIONS.
   For the purpose of this subchapter, the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
   CLEANING AND DYEING ESTABLISH- MENT. Any place or vehicle where the service
of dry cleaning, wet cleaning as a process incidental to dry cleaning, dyeing,
spotting or finishing any fabric is rendered for hire or is sold, resold or
offered for sale or resale.
   CLEANING PLANT. Any cleaning and dyeing establishment equipped to perform
dry cleaning.
   DRY CLEANING. The process of cleaning fabrics by immersion and agitation, or
by immersion only, in volatile solvents (including, but not by way of
limitation, solvents of petroleum distillate type, the coal tar distillate type
and the chlorinated hydrocarbon type) and processes incidental thereto
(including, but without limitation, spotting, cleaning, wet cleaning and
finishing).
   FABRIC. Any article of wearing apparel, household furnishings, rugs,
textiles, fur and leather.
   FINISHING. The process of pressing or reshaping any fabric which is designed
to restore as nearly as possible the shape, dimensions and contour of the
fabric.
   PROPRIETOR. Any person by or for whom a cleaning plant is operated.
   RETAIL OUTLET. Any cleaning and dyeing establishment located within the city
where dry cleaning is sold, solicited or offered for sale directly to the
retail consumer. Includes any automobile, truck or other vehicle, operated
within the city, from which dry cleaning is sold, solicited or offered for sale
directly to the retail consumer.
   RETAILER. Any person or member of the cleaning and dyeing trade by or for
whom a retail outlet is operated.
   SPOTTING. The process designed to remove spots or stains which remain in a
fabric after it has been subjected to the other process of dry cleaning.
(Prior Code, § 117.015)
§ 117.016 INSPECTION AND CERTIFICATE REQUIRED.
   To promote and protect the public health of the city and to remove and
prevent fire hazards, every cleaning and dyeing establishment, cleaning plant
and retail outlet located within the city and every cleaning and dyeing
establishment which is not located within the city, but has a retail outlet
operating in the city shall be regularly inspected and shall obtain a
certificate of inspection as hereinafter provided.
(Prior Code, § 117.016) Penalty, see §
10.99
§ 117.017 SANITATION REQUIREMENTS.
   (A)   Every building or premises used or occupied by a cleaning and dyeing
establishment, cleaning plant or retail outlet located within the city or used
or occupied by a cleaning and dyeing plant not located in the city, but which
has a retail outlet in the city shall be kept in a clean and sanitary condition
as to its floors, sidewalls, ceilings, woodwork and fixtures and as to the
tools, machinery, equipment and storage facilities used and kept in any such
building or premises.
   (B)   At regular intervals and at other times as may be deemed necessary and
as shall be specified by the Commissioner of Health, the floors, sidewalls,
ceilings, woodwork and fixtures of any such building and premises and the
tools, machinery, equipment and storage facilities used or kept thereon shall
be washed or sprayed with a disinfectant in solution of other liquid form or
vapor approved by the Commissioner of Health.
(Prior Code, § 117.017) Penalty, see §
10.99
§ 117.018 DISEASED PERSONS NOT TO BE EMPLOYED.
   No person affected or afflicted with tuberculosis or any other infectious or
communicable disease shall be employed in any dry cleaning establishment,
cleaning plant or retail outlet located within the city or in any cleaning and
dyeing establishment or cleaning plant which is not located in the city but
which has a retail outlet therein. The Commissioner of Health of the city may
require each employee of such cleaning and dyeing plant, cleaning plant or
retail outlet to be examined by a licensed and practicing physician and may
require any proprietor or retailer to file in the office of the Commissioner of
Health a certificate of health and freedom from tuberculosis or other
infectious or communicable disease for each person employed by the proprietor
as a proprietor or retailer, which certificate shall be signed by a licensed
and practicing physician.
(Prior Code, § 117.018) Penalty, see §
10.99
§ 117.019 CLEANING STANDARDS.
   (A)   No finished or unfinished dry cleaning sold, solicited or offered for
sale within the city shall show, upon the dry cleaned fabric being re-rinsed in
water-white solvent (one gallon to one pound of garment weight), sufficient
dirt or soil residue or other foreign deposits sufficient to darken dry solvent
below 15 Saybolt Chorometer.
   (B)   Finished dry cleaning sold, solicited or offered for sale within the
city shall be free from solvent and chemical odors.
   (C)   No chemical or other substance which is poisonous, injurious or
unwholesome to human beings and which is not essential to the service or
process of dry cleaning, dyeing, spotting or finishing shall be used in
rendering any such service or performing any such process in any cleaning and
dyeing plant located within the city or in any cleaning and dyeing plant or
cleaning plant which is not located within the city, but has a retail outlet
within the city.
   (D)   In case any such chemical or other substance which is poisonous,
injurious or unwholesome to human beings is used by any cleaning and dyeing
establishment or cleaning plant in rendering any such service or performing any
such process essential thereto, then such chemical or other substance shall be
completely removed from the fabric dry cleaned, dyed or spotted or finished or
such chemical or other substance shall be completely and entirely neutralized
and rendered harmless and innoxious to human beings before such fabric is
permitted to leave such establishment or plant for delivery to the person
entitled to the possession thereof upon completion of the process.
(Prior Code, § 117.019) Penalty, see §
10.99
§ 117.020 INSPECTION FOR FIRE HAZARD.
   The Chief of the Fire Department of the city shall have the right to enter
any building or premises situated within the city and used or occupied by any
cleaning and dyeing establishment, cleaning plant or retail outlet in order to
examine same and to determine whether or not said building and premises, or any
material, article or fabric dry cleaned, dyed, spotted or finished as received,
used, kept, maintained or stored on the building or premises conforms to the
Fire Prevention Code within the city.
(Prior Code, § 117.020)
§ 117.021 CERTIFICATE OF INSPECTION.
   (A)   Every proprietor or retailer of each cleaning plant located within the
city and of each cleaning and dyeing establishment and cleaning plant which is
not located within the city, but which has a retail outlet in the city, shall
make written application in duplicate to the City Clerk for the issuance to
applicant of a certificate of inspection.
   (B)   In the case of cleaning and dyeing establishments and cleaning plants
located within the city, one copy of the application shall be delivered to the
Commissioner of Health and the other copy shall be delivered to the Chief of
the Fire Department of the city. Within 15 days after the filing of such
application the Commissioner of Health and Chief of the Fire Department shall
cause an inspection to be made of the building and premises on which the
cleaning and dyeing establishment or cleaning plant is located, the floor,
sidewalls, ceiling, woodwork, fixtures, tools, machinery, equipment, storage
facilities and delivery trucks. The Commissioner of Health may require health
certificates to be filed for each employee of the applicant within 15 days
after the application is filed or at any time thereafter. The Commissioner of
Health may also require that any employee be examined by a competent licensed
physician practicing within the city. Upon the completion of their respective
inspections, the Commissioner of Health and Chief of the Fire Department shall
determine whether the establishment, plant or outlet mentioned in the
application, and examined by them, is used, maintained and operated in
conformity with the provisions of this chapter. If their determination is
negative, they shall deny the application. In case the Commissioner of Health
and Chief of the Fire Department are not able to agree, they shall submit the
facts disclosed by their respective investigations to the City Council, which,
upon being fully advised, shall decide whether or not the application shall be
allowed or denied.
   (C)   In the case of cleaning and dyeing establishments or cleaning plants
which are not located within the city, but which have a retail outlet located
in the city, one copy of the application shall be delivered to the Commissioner
of Health. Within 15 days after filing of the application, the Commissioner of
Health shall make or cause to be made an inspection of the building or premises
on which the cleaning and dyeing establishment or cleaning plant is located,
the floors, sidewalls, ceilings, woodwork, fixtures, tools, machinery,
equipment, storage facilities and any delivery vehicle. The Commissioner of
Health may require health certificates to be filed for each person employed by
the applicant in the establishment or plant and in any retail outlet located
within the city within 15 days after any application is filed or at any time
thereafter. The Commissioner may require that any employee be examined by a
competent licensed and practicing physician. Upon the completion of the
inspection, the Commissioner of Health shall determine whether the
establishment or plant or outlet mentioned in the application, and examined by
the Commissioner, is used, maintained and operated in conformity with the
provisions of this chapter. If his or her determination is in the affirmative,
he or she shall allow the application. If his or her determination is in the
negative, he or she shall deny the application. Any applicant whose application
is denied may take an appeal from the decision of the Commissioner of Health to
the City Council.
   (D)   In the case of retail outlets not situated in the same building or
premises with a cleaning and dyeing establishment or cleaning plant, an
inspection shall be made under the direction of the Commissioner of Health and
the Chief of the Fire Department for the purpose of determining whether the
outlet is used, maintained and operated in conformity with the provisions of
this subchapter. A certificate of inspection shall be issued upon the same
conditions and in the same manner as above prescribed for cleaning and dyeing
establishments and cleaning plants located within the city, and the application
for a certificate shall be in all respects the same as in the case of such
establishments or plants. Retail outlets situated on the same premises as a
cleaning and dyeing establishment or cleaning plant shall be inspected at the
same time and in the same manner as the establishment or plant. Where several
cleaning and dyeing establishments, cleaning plants or retail outlets are
operated by a single proprietor or in conjunction with each other, a single
application may be filed for a certificate of inspection for each
establishment, plant or retail outlet.
   (E)   All certificates of inspection shall be signed by the Mayor of the
city and shall be attested by the City Clerk.
   (F)   An applicant, if the applicant so requests, shall be personally heard
by the officials or representatives of the city who are required to pass upon
the application, prior to the determination. Upon appeal, if the applicant so
requests, an applicant shall be heard by the City Council prior to its
determination of the appeal.
   (G)   In case any application is denied either by the official or officials
to whom the same is presented in accordance with the provisions hereof, or by
the City Council upon appeal thereto, the applicant whose application is so
denied may file a new application; provided that, the application shall be
accompanied with a statement under oath that the facts which caused the denial
of the previous application no longer exist.
(Prior Code, § 117.021)
§ 117.022 INSPECTION FEES.
   (A)   At the time of filing an application for a certificate of inspection
for any cleaning and dyeing establishment or cleaning plant as above provided,
the applicant shall pay an inspection fee in the amount set forth in the
Building Department fee schedule for the inspection of any cleaning plant as
defied in §
117.015 of this chapter.
   (B)   No additional inspection fee shall be charged or paid for the
inspection of or issuance of a certificate of inspection for any retail outlet
situated in the same building or on the same premises as a cleaning and dyeing
establishment or cleaning plant in conjunction with which it is operated. The
inspection fee for any such retail outlet operated in conjunction with such
establishment or plant and not situated in the same building or on the same
premises shall be in the amount set forth in the Building Department fee
schedule. For the purposes of this section, each automobile, truck or other
vehicle operated within the city from which dry cleaning is sold, solicited or
offered for sale directly to the retail consumer shall be considered a separate
retail outlet and shall be subject to inspection and to the inspection fee in
the amount set forth in the Building Department fee schedule.
(Prior Code, § 117.022) (Ord. 2038, passed 3-23-1976)
§ 117.023 TERM OF CERTIFICATE; RENEWAL.
   Each certificate shall expire the April 30 next following the date on which
the certificate is issued. Application for renewal shall be filed on or before
the first Monday of the month during which it will expire. At the time of
filing a renewal application, an inspection fee shall be paid to the City Clerk
in the same amount as the application for the original certificate. Upon the
filing of an application for renewal of a certificate and payment of the
inspection fee, the application shall be investigated and the establishment,
plant, outlet and persons employed therein shall be inspected and investigated.
The procedure on application for renewal shall be in all things the same as the
application for the original certificate and the determination thereof.
(Prior Code, § 117.023)
§ 117.024 CERTIFICATE FOR RETAIL OUTLET.
   A certificate of inspection shall not be issued to or for any retail outlet
until and unless each cleaning and dyeing establishment or cleaning plant for
which it is a retail outlet has been issued a certificate of inspection. A
revocation, suspension or expiration of the certificate of inspection of any
cleaning and dyeing establishment or cleaning plant shall automatically act as
a revocation, suspension or expiration respectively of the certificate of
inspection of each retail outlet located within the city.
(Prior Code, § 117.024)
§ 117.025 PERIODIC INSPECTIONS; REVOCATION OR SUSPENSION OF CERTIFICATE.
   (A)   The Commissioner of Health shall cause periodic investigations and
inspections to be made of cleaning and dyeing establishments, cleaning plants
and retail outlets for which certificates of inspection have been issued.
   (B)   Violation of any provision of this subchapter shall be cause for
revocation or suspension of a certificate of inspection. Upon notice and public
hearing, the Commissioner of Health may revoke any certificate of inspection
issued, or may suspend any certificate for a period of not more than 30 days.
An appeal may be taken to the City Council from any decision rendered by the
Commissioner of Health under the provisions of this section.
(Prior Code, § 117.025)
SELF-SERVICE DRY CLEANING
§ 117.040 DEFINITION.
   For the purpose of this subchapter, the following definition shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
   SELF-SERVICE DRY CLEANING STORE. Any store, room or other enclosed place
within any building where any number of self-service dry cleaning machines, all
controlled and operated by means of automatic coin-metering devices, are
located and open to use by the public.
(Prior Code, § 117.040) (Ord. 1919, passed 11-12-1962)
§ 117.041 LICENSE REQUIRED.
   No person shall own or operate any self-service dry cleaning establishment
in the city without first having obtained a license.
(Prior Code, § 117.041) (Ord. 1919, passed 11-12-1962) Penalty, see §
10.99
§ 117.042 APPLICATION FOR LICENSE.
   Any person desiring a license for a self-service dry cleaning store shall
make application in writing to the City Clerk. The application shall, among
other things, state the name and address of the person requesting the license,
the location of the store to be licensed and the number and description of the
self-service dry cleaning machines to be located in the store. In the case of
an original application for a store not theretofore legally in operation, the
application shall be accompanied by a set of plans and specifications showing
the manner in which the machines shall be installed, showing all plumbing
connections, electrical wire connections and provisions for ventilation, all of
which shall be in compliance with the Building Code, the Fire Code and other
applicable ordinances of the city. In the case of an initial application, the
City Clerk shall submit the plans and specifications to the Building
Commissioner of the city for his or her examination and approval before the
issuance of any license.
(Prior Code, § 117.042) (Ord. 1919, passed 11-12-1962)
§ 117.043 LICENSE FEE; FOOD DISPENSING MACHINES NOT AUTHORIZED.
   The annual fee for a self-service dry cleaning store shall be $25, plus $25
for each self-service dry cleaning machine. Every license shall expire on the
April 30 next after its issuance. Upon the initial issuance of a license, the
fee shall be prorated from the first day of the month in which the license is
issued to the end of the then current license year. The license fee shall not
cover, nor shall it authorize, the use or maintenance in any self-service dry
cleaning store of an automatic food or beverage dispensing device or machine.
Any automatic food or beverage dispensing device or machine which may be
installed or located in the self-service cleaning store shall be installed in
compliance with and subject to the requirements or any ordinance of the city
now or hereafter in effect licensing and regulating automatic food or beverage
dispensing machines or devices.
(Prior Code, § 117.043) (Ord. 1919, passed 11-12-1962)
§ 117.044 INSTALLATION AND OPERATION REQUIREMENTS.
   Every licensee to whom a license shall be issued hereunder shall cause the
self-service dry cleaning store for which the license is issued to be
maintained and operated so as to satisfy the following requirements.
   (A)   Installation.
      (1)   Machines shall not be installed in buildings used in whole or in
part as dwellings.
      (2)   A satisfactory means of preventing any leaking liquid from escaping
the enclosure or room in which the dry cleaning equipment is installed shall be
provided. In order to accomplish this, a method must be provided for draining
or otherwise removing the solvent in the event of leakage. Such drain shall be
connected to an emergency solvent storage tank of sufficient capacity to hold
the maximum quantity of fluid contained in all the machines.
      (3)   An interlock system shall be provided on each machine to prevent
the loading door from being opened during the normal cycle. This system may be
either electrical or mechanical and so connected that, in the event of a power
failure, the machine fails safe.
      (4)   Exhaust ventilation stacks from the dry cleaning machines shall not
be located in proximity to combustion air intakes on gas or oil fired
equipment.
      (5)   The layout of each store shall be such that only the front or
customer side of the dry cleaning machines shall be readily accessible to the
customer area and that the maintenance portions of the machines shall not be
accessible from the customer area.
   (B)   Operation.
      (1)   An attendant shall be present and on duty during all operational
hours of each store.
      (2)   Only the solvent and supplies specified by the equipment
manufacturer shall be used; provided, however, that, in no event shall an
inflammable solvent be used in the dry cleaning machines.
      (3)   The solvent shall be stored in closed containers and transferred
from such containers in lines free of leaks or defects. All storage facilities
for solvent external from the dry cleaning machines shall meet the requirements
of the Fire Chief.
      (4)   Filter residue and other residues containing solvent shall be
handled and disposed of so as not to create a nuisance. A covered metal
container shall be used for temporary storage.
      (5)   The design of each dry cleaning machine shall be such that in the
normal course of operation no significant amount of solvent is retained in the
cleaned items upon completion of the dry cleaning cycle.
      (6)   (a)   Customer service areas of each store shall be provided with
general dilution ventilation (exhaust air flow rates) according to the
following schedule:
 
Number of Machines (C.F.M.) Minimum Air Flow Rate per Machine
1—3                       250
4—8                       200
9—16                      150
17 or more                  100
 
         (b)   This exhaust ventilation shall be in continuous operation during
all operational hours of each store.
      (7)   Maintenance areas of each store shall be provided with general
dilution ventilation (exhaust air flow rates) according to the following
schedule:
 
Number of Machines (C.F.M.) Minimum Air Flow Rate Per Machine
1—3                       350
4—8                       300
9—16                      250
17 or more                  200
 
      (8)   All exhaust ventilation equipment required under divisions (B)(6)
and (B)(7) above shall be in operation on a continuous basis during the hours
each store is open to the public. The fan wiring of the exhaust equipment shall
be such that the dry cleaning machines cannot be operated unless the fan system
is in operation.
      (9)   Each dry cleaning machine shall be provided with an exhaust system
capable of maintaining a minimum of 100 feet per minute face velocity through
the loading door whenever the door is open, which exhaust system shall be in
operation during all times of operation of the dry cleaning machine to which it
is affixed. The dual work connections from this system shall be sealed by
solder or tape and the discharge stack extended above the roof line.
      (10)   A supply of make-up air equal to or greater than the total volume
of air exhausted from the store shall be provided for the purpose of
eliminating negative pressure conditions.
      (11)   All machinery and equipment shall be kept in good working
condition and installed and maintained so that the customers of the store and
the public generally will neither have access to the maintenance area nor to
any unguarded moving parts of the machinery; except that, the customers shall
have access to the operating controls of the dry cleaning machines.
      (12)   The premises shall be kept in good repair and maintained in a
clean and sanitary condition. A step-by-step instruction list shall be posted
in a conspicuous place for customer use near the dry cleaning machines. All
maintenance personnel shall be instructed in the proper procedures for the
handling of solvents.
      (13)   Each store shall be kept well lighted during all of the hours when
it is open for business. If off-street parking is provided for automobiles of
customers of the store, the off-street parking area or areas shall be surfaced
with crushed stone or other suitable hard surface materials, shall be level,
shall be provided with adequate driveway or driveways for ingress or egress,
and shall be well lighted during all the hours of darkness.
(Prior Code, § 117.044) (Ord. 1919, passed 11-12-1962) Penalty, see §
10.99
LAUNDRIES
§ 117.055 LICENSE REQUIRED.
   No person shall conduct a laundry in the city without first obtaining a
license so to do.
(Prior Code, § 117.055) Penalty, see §
10.99
§ 117.056 APPLICATION FOR LICENSE.
   Any person desiring to conduct a laundry in the city shall make application
therefor to the City Clerk, which application shall state the name of the
person owning and conducting such laundry and the location of the laundry and,
upon the payment of the license fee, shall be granted a license, attested by
the proper city authorities, authorizing the applicant to conduct a laundry at
the place designated in the application.
(Prior Code, § 117.056)
§ 117.057 LICENSE FEE.
   The license fee to be paid by such applicant shall be the sum of $25 per
annum and all licenses shall expire on April 30 following the date of issuance
of the license. If any license be granted for less than one year, the license
fee shall be reduced pro rata.
(Prior Code, § 117.057)
§ 117.058 LOCATION OF BOUNDARIES; BUILDING PERMIT.
   (A)   No person, firm or corporation shall locate, build, construct or
maintain on any street, avenue or alley in the city, in any block in which one-
half of the buildings on both sides of the street, avenue or alley are used
exclusively for residence purposes, any building for a laundry to be run by
machinery, without the written consent of a majority of the property owners
according to frontage, on both sides of such street, avenue or alley.
   (B)   Written consent shall be obtained and filed with the City Clerk before
a permit is issued for the construction of any such building; provided that, in
determining whether one-half of the buildings on both sides of the street,
avenue or alley are used exclusively for residence purposes, any building
fronting upon another street, avenue or alley and located upon a corner lot
shall not be considered.
(Prior Code, § 117.058) Penalty, see §
10.99
LAUNDRY VEHICLES AND OUTLETS
§ 117.070 DEFINITIONS.
   For the purpose of this subchapter, the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
   LAUNDRY OUTLET. Any establishment located within the city (other than a
laundry vehicle and other than a laundry licensed under the provisions of §§
117.055 to
117.058 of this chapter), used for the purpose of soliciting, receiving,
collecting or distributing laundry within the city limits.
   LAUNDRY VEHICLE. Any wagon, automobile or other vehicle used for the purpose
of collecting or delivering laundry within the city limits.
(Prior Code, § 117.070) (Ord. 1508, passed 10-27-1941)
§ 117.071 LICENSE REQUIRED.
   No person shall establish, maintain, operate or cause to be operated any
laundry outlet or laundry vehicle within the city limits without first having
obtained a license for the same.
(Prior Code, § 117.071) (Ord. 1508, passed 10-27-1941) Penalty, see §
10.99
§ 117.072 APPLICATION FOR LICENSE.
   (A)   Any person desiring to maintain or operate a laundry outlet or laundry
vehicle in the city shall make application to the City Clerk for a license so
to do, which application shall state the name of the person who owns or
operates the laundry outlet or laundry vehicle, as the case may be, and in the
case of a laundry outlet, the street address thereof, and in the case of a
laundry vehicle, the name and type of the vehicle and the street address of the
place where the same is kept or stored when not in use.
   (B)   Upon payment of the license fee, and upon compliance with the
requirements of this subchapter, a license shall be issued authorizing the
applicant to maintain or operate a laundry outlet or outlets or a laundry
vehicle or vehicles or both as the case may be, and the City Clerk shall issue
a suitable emblem which shall bear the words “laundry outlet” or “laundry
vehicle”, as the case may be, which such emblem shall be displayed in a
conspicuous place in the laundry outlet or shall be attached to such laundry
vehicle in a plainly conspicuous place.
(Prior Code, § 117.072) (Ord. 1508, passed 10-27-1941)
§ 117.073 LICENSE FEE.
   The annual license fee for each laundry outlet or laundry vehicle shall be
$10; provided, however, that, any person operating a laundry licensed under the
provisions of §§
117.055 to
117.058 of this chapter, who uses any vehicle in connection with such licensed
laundry, shall be entitled to receive a laundry vehicle license for each such
laundry vehicle for the sum of $5. No license shall be issued, except for the
full license fee.
(Prior Code, § 117.073) (Ord. 1508, passed 10-27-1941)
§ 117.074 NAME TO BE DISPLAYED ON VEHICLE.
   No vehicle of any kind shall be used for the purpose of collecting or
delivering laundry work, unless such vehicle shall carry upon two sides of the
same in plain, legible letters, at least one and one-half inches high, the name
of the laundry where the laundry work is actually done.
(Prior Code, § 117.074) (Ord. 1508, passed 10-27-1941) Penalty, see §
10.99
§ 117.075 SANITARY REQUIREMENTS.
   All laundry outlets and laundry vehicles for the transportation of laundry
shall at all times be kept in a clean and sanitary condition and be properly
equipped with means to separate the laundered from the unlaundered articles.
Every laundry outlet and laundry vehicle shall have separate containers for
bedding, linen and wearing apparel which may be taken from places where
quarantine has been established or where persons are afflicted with or are
convalescing after a disease. Laundry outlets and laundry vehicles shall be
inspected under the direction of the Health Commissioner of the city as often
and at such times as the Health Commissioner may deem necessary or proper in
order to keep them in a proper sanitary condition.
(Prior Code, § 117.075) (Ord. 1508, passed 10-27-1941)

BUILDING MATERIAL DEALERS
§ 118.001 LICENSE REQUIRED.
   No person shall sell or offer for sale cement, brick, stone, lime, plaster,
sand, sewer pipe or other building material in the city without obtaining a
license.
(Prior Code, § 118.001) Penalty, see §
10.99
§ 118.002 APPLICATION FOR LICENSE.
   (A)   Any person desiring to sell or offer for sale any of the building
material mentioned in §
118.001 of this chapter shall make application to the City Clerk for a license.
   (B)   The application shall set forth the name of the applicant and the
place of the business.
   (C)   Upon the payment of the license fee, the City Clerk shall issue to the
applicant a license, attested by the proper city authorities, authorizing the
applicant to sell or offer for sale any of the building material mentioned in §
118.001 of this chapter; provided that, if any person has taken out a license
authorizing the sale of lumber or authorizing the conducting of a lumberyard,
no further license shall be required for the sale of the building material
described herein.
(Prior Code, § 118.002)
§ 118.003 LICENSE FEE.
   The license fee shall be $75 per annum, in accordance with the business
licensing fee schedule. All licenses shall expire on the April 30 next
succeeding the date of issuance of the license. If a license is granted for
less than one year, the license fee shall be reduced pro rata.
(Prior Code, § 118.003) (Ord. 2321, passed 3-23-1976)
CONTRACTORS
§ 118.015 DEFINITION.
   For the purpose of this subchapter, the following definition shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
   CONTRACTOR. One who enters into a contract for the erection or repair of
buildings, for the installing of heating and for plumbing, for the installing
of electric wiring or equipment, for the laying of sidewalks, or for the
painting of chattels or the interior or exterior of buildings, or for
paperhanging.
(Prior Code, § 118.015)
§ 118.016 LICENSE REQUIRED.
   No person shall engage in the business of a contractor, as above defined,
without first obtaining a license so to do.
(Prior Code, § 118.016) Penalty, see §
10.99
§ 118.017 APPLICATION FOR LICENSE.
   Any person desiring to engage in the business of a contractor, as above
defined, shall make application to the City Clerk for a license so to do. The
application shall state the name of the applicant, the applicant’s residence or
place of business, the kind of business engaged in, and such other information
as shall be desired by the City Clerk.
(Prior Code, § 118.017)
§ 118.018 LICENSE FEE.
   The annual license fee to be paid by the applicant desiring to be licensed
as a contractor shall be $60 per year; provided that, if the contractor engages
only in the applying of siding to the exterior of buildings or the repair or
construction of roofs or in the painting of the exterior or interior of non-
residential buildings, and/or paperhanging, the license shall be $30. If the
contractor engages only in the painting of the exterior or interior of
residential buildings, the contractor shall not be charged a license fee. All
licenses shall expire one year after the date of issuance.
(Prior Code, § 118.018) (Ord. 1669, passed 4-14-1952; Ord. 87-71, passed 3-10-
1987; Ord. 2025-030, passed 6-24-2025)
§ 118.019 INSURANCE REQUIRED.
   No contractor’s license shall be issued pursuant to this chapter until the
applicant for such license provides a Certificate of Insurance naming the city
as the Certificate holder. The minimum insurance requirements are $1,000,000
per occurrence for general liability and the statutory minimum for Workers
Compensation.
(Ord. 2025-030, passed 6-24-2025)
ELECTRICAL CONTRACTORS
§ 118.030 DEFINITION.
   For the purpose of this subchapter, the following definition shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
   ELECTRICAL CONTRACTOR. Any person engaged in the business of installing or
altering by contract electrical equipment for the utilization of electricity
for light, heat or power. But the term ELECTRICAL CONTRACTOR shall not include
the installing or altering of radio apparatus or equipment for wireless
reception of sounds and signals; or apparatus, conductors or other equipment
installed for or by public utilities, including common carriers, which are
under the jurisdiction of the State Commerce Commission, for use in their
operation as public utilities; nor shall the term include the employees
employed by an ELECTRICAL CONTRACTOR to do or supervise the contractor’s work.
(Prior Code, § 118.030) (Ord. 1591, passed 2-23-1948)
§ 118.031 REGISTRATION REQUIRED.
   No person shall engage in the business of an electrical contractor as in §
118.030 of this chapter defined without first having registered with the City
Clerk and having paid the registration fee as herein required; provided,
however, that, an electrical contractor who is registered in another
municipality shall not be required to be registered or to pay the registration
fee as provided herein.
(Prior Code, § 118.031) (Ord. 1591, passed 2-23-1948) Penalty, see §
10.99
§ 118.032 ANNUAL REGISTRATION FEE.
   The annual registration fee for every electrical contractor who shall
register with the City Clerk shall be $30 and the period of registration shall
be from May 1 to April 30 of the year following; providing that, any
registration made subsequent to May 1 shall expire on April 30 following such
registration.
(Prior Code, § 118.032) (Ord. 1591, passed 2-23-1948; Ord. 1669, passed 4-14-
1952)
§ 118.033 COMPLIANCE WITH ORDINANCES REQUIRED.
   Every electrical contractor shall comply with all ordinances of the city now
or hereafter in force with respect to buildings and their construction,
erection and alteration.
(Prior Code, § 118.033) (Ord. 1591, passed 2-23-1948) Penalty, see §
10.99
LUMBERYARDS
§ 118.045 LICENSE REQUIRED.
   No person shall keep, carry on, conduct or maintain a lumberyard or other
place where lumber is sold from a yard, car or place where lumber is stored for
the purpose of seasoning or drying the same, or where secondhand lumber is
stored or kept for sale, without first obtaining a license.
(Prior Code, § 118.045) Penalty, see §
10.99
§ 118.046 APPLICATION FOR LICENSE.
   Any person desiring to keep, conduct or maintain a lumberyard or a place for
the sale, storing or keeping of lumber as described in §
118.045 of this chapter shall make application in writing to the City Clerk for
a license. The application shall set forth the name of the applicant and the
place where it is desired to keep the lumberyard or the place to be used for
the storage or sale of lumber. After the payment of the license fee, the City
Clerk shall issue to the applicant a license, attested by the proper city
authorities, authorizing the applicant to keep, conduct or maintain a
lumberyard or place for the storage or sale of lumber at the place designated
in the application.
(Prior Code, § 118.046)
§ 118.047 LICENSE FEE.
   The license fee shall be $25 per year. All licenses shall expire on the
April 30 next after the date of the issuance. If a license is granted for less
than one year, the license fee shall be reduced pro rata.
(Prior Code, § 118.047) (Ord. 1669, passed 4-14-1952)
MACHINE SHOPS
§ 118.060 DEFINITION.
   For the purpose of this subchapter, the following definition shall apply
unless the context, clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
   MACHINE SHOP. A work shop in which machines are made or metal parts thereof
are made or are repaired or where parts of machines or tools, implements,
gears, dies, screws or other metal articles are cut, filed, shaped, punched,
stamped or repaired by means of a lathe or other machinery.
(Prior Code, § 118.060) (Ord. 1667, passed 4-14-1952)
§ 118.061 LICENSE REQUIRED.
   No person shall conduct or operate a machine shop within the limits of the
city without first having obtained a license therefor.
(Prior Code, § 118.061) (Ord. 1667, passed 4-14-1952) Penalty, see §
10.99
§ 118.062 LICENSE FEES.
   The annual fee for each machine shop license shall be based on the number of
persons engaged therein as follows:
 
Not more than 2 persons $25
3 to 10 persons         $35
11 to 25 persons        $50
Over 25 persons         $75
 
(Prior Code, § 118.062) (Ord. 1667, passed 4-14-1952)
§ 118.063 SAFETY AND HEALTH REGULATIONS.
   No building, structure or part thereof used for or in connection with any
machine shop shall be used so as to endanger the health or property of the
employees or of the public. The owner or operator of any machine shop shall
cause all floors and other surface around or beneath any machine or work bench
to be kept in good order and repair and shall have suitable and convenient
sanitary receptacles for receiving waste and cloths used in and about the
machine shop for the purpose of cleaning machines or parts thereof. The owner
or operator shall not permit any steel cuttings or machine parts to accumulate
on or about any machine or work bench so that the same may become detrimental
to the health or safety of any person therein engaged.
(Prior Code, § 118.063) (Ord. 1667, passed 4-14-1952) Penalty, see §
10.99
ROOFERS
§ 118.075 DEFINITION.
   For the purpose of this subchapter, the following definition shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
   ROOFER. Every person engaged in the business of constructing roofs or
repairing, recoating, altering or changing roofs of buildings or other
structures within the city.
(Prior Code, § 118.075)
§ 118.076 APPLICATION FOR LICENSE.
   Every roofer shall, before putting on any roof or repairing, recoating,
altering or changing any roof of any building or other structure within the
city, make application to the City Clerk for a roofer’s license.
(Prior Code, § 118.076) Penalty, see §
10.99
§ 118.077 LICENSE FEE; PERMITTED ACTIVITIES.
   The application shall state the name of the applicant, the applicant’s
residence, place of business and such other information as may be pertinent and
upon the payment of a license fee of $25 per year there shall be issued to such
person a license permitting the licensee to engage in the city in the business
of roofer as herein defined; provided that, the license shall also entitle the
licensee to engage in the work of repairing the sides of buildings by affixing
prepared asphalt or asbestos or other similar materials thereto, but the
license shall not permit the licensee to engage in the business or activities
of a general contractor.
(Prior Code, § 118.077)
§ 118.078 EXEMPTION.
   (A)   If the applicant for a roofer’s license has been granted by the city a
general contractor’s license as required by §§
118.015 to
118.018 of this chapter, it shall not be necessary for such applicant to secure
a roofer’s license.
   (B)   The securing of such roofer’s license shall in no way affect the
provisions of the Building Code, with reference to the necessity of securing a
permit for the erection, enlargement, alteration or repair of any building in
the city, nor in any way affect the payment of the fees required by the
Building Code for such permit.
(Prior Code, § 118.078)
